I gave her 2s. 1/2 d., and a duplicate to go and get a pair of shoes, which were pawned for Is., and a bed gown pawned for 8d.—the prosecutor then said he was robbed of 8s.—I said all I had was 2s. 4 1/2 d.—Wood went to get the things, and the officer took her.
Wood's Defence. Brown gave me the 2s. 1/2 d. to go and get the things; as I was going across the road, the gentleman said, "Here is an officer for you, "and he gave me in charge.
JOHN MARTIN (police-constable R 219.) I produce a certificate of Wood's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—she is the person.

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 28.

WOOD—
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Twelve Months.

2435.
JAMES STOREY was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of August, 1 flageolet, value 10s.; the goods of
John Wells.
JONATHAN WHEELER . I am a police sergeant. On the 24th of

August, I was passing John-street, Tottenham Court-road, and sat the prisoner with this flageolet under his jacket—I stopped him, and asked whose it was—he said, his father's, and he was going to take it to Clerkenwell, which was quite a different way to what he was going—I took him, and found on him this brass cock.

JOHN WELLS . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Adam's-row, Hamp
stead—this is my flageolet—I lost it on the 24th—I saw it safe at my stall outside my shop an hour before.
Prisoner. I found it lying down on the ground, and put it under my jacket.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined One Month.

div0.p: First Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
2436.
HENRY WILLIAM SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of August, 1 coat, value 1l. 10s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 20s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 5s.; and 3 handkerchiefs, value 5s., the goods of
James Smith; to which he pleaded.

GUILTY .*—
Confined Three Months.

2437.
EDWIN BENNETT was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of August, 1 plane, value 2s.; 1 auger, value 1s.; 2 squares, value 5s.; 2 wrenches, value 4s.; 1 chisel, value 1s.; 1 rule, value 6d.; 1 spoke
shave, value 6d.; and 7 pencils, value 1s.; also,
on the 1st of August, 10 planes, value 1l. 2s.; 1 auger, value 1s.; 1 spoke-shave, value 2s.; 1 knife, value 2s.; 1 stock, value 10s.; and 27 bits, value 10s.; the goods of
Cornelius Clive: to both of which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 25.—Recommended to mercy .—
Confined Four Months.

2438.
ELIZABETH HANSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of August, 38 yards of printed cotton, value 1l. 10s., the goods of
Edward Day; to which she pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 16.—Recommended to mercy .—
Confined Four Months.

2439.
THOMAS HARDY was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of August, 1 umbrella, value 6s., the goods of
Daniel Box; to which be pleaded

GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy .—
Confined One Month.

2440.
THOMAS WHITE was indicted
for embezzlement; to which he pleaded.

GUILTY .—
Confined Twelve Months.

2441.
ELIZABETH CHESSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of June, at
Christchurch, 10 sovereigns, 5 half-sovereigns, 4 crowns, 22 half-crowns, 250 shillings, 50 sixpences, and one handkerchief, value 1s.; the property of
Maria Howie, her mistress, in her dwelling-house; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Four Months.

2442.
JAMES WOOLF was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of August, one carpet, value 12s. 3d., the goods of
George Nicholson.

THOMAS GREEN . I am in the employ of George Nicholson, a carpet-warehouseman, in Aldgate—this carpet is his property—I saw it safe at seven o'clock last Friday evening, hanging at the door-post for sale—about an hour after I received information, and missed it.

CORNELIUS FOAY . I am a policeman. On Friday evening, the 26th of August, at eight o'clock, I saw the prisoner carrying a bundle in High-street, about 200 yards from the prosecutor's—he saw me, and ran down a court—I went after him, and caught him with the bundle—I asked what he had got, and where he got it—he said a man had given him sixpence to carry it—he dropped it at his feet—I took it up—it was this carpet.
Prisoners Defence. A man asked me to carry it to Cattle-street, and gave me sixpence; I carried it to Castle-street, and put it down; the policeman came and collared me.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Three Months.
Before Mr. Baron Rolfe.

2443.
EDWARD LEADER was indicted
for a rape.

GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 39.—
Confined Two Years.

2444.
ELIZABETH NEWARK was indicted
for feloniously killing and slaying
William Meynell Oates.
MR. PRENDEROAST conducted the Prosecution,

SARAH CLIFFORD . Hive at the Sovereign public-house, in Munster-street. On Wednesday, the 13th of July, about halt-past three o'clock in the after
noon, the deceased came to our house very tipsy—he went to sleep, and fell off the seat, and grazed his upper lip—the prisoner came in about half-past five—I believe she had a key in her hand—I believe she called the deceased "My Lord Tom Noddy"—I did not hear him say any thing to her—I was drawing some gin at the time—I believe she struck him, but I did not see her—I saw he had a mark on his face at the top of the nose, afterwards, and it bled—I did not see the key—somebody bathed his face.

CAROLINE DAVIS . On Wednesday, the 13th of July, I went into the Sovereign, in Munster-street, and remained there—Oates was there when I went in—I saw the prisoner come in, at very nearly five o'clock, the first time—she went out with three more females, and came in again with a large key in her hand—the deceased was rather reclining on his seat before the bar—she tapped him on his shoulder, and called him "My Lord Tom Noddy"—he said he would have none of her d——nonsense—she said, "Take that," and hit him on the right hand with the key—he then called her an Irish prostitute—she then ran at him, and struck him under the right eye with the key, which was on her fore-finger—he bled very much—I borrowed a handkerchief, and wiped and bathed it—the skin was broken—I did not stop with him—he said he did not care much about it—I said, "Don't be stupid, hold the handkerchief up to your face"—he appeared to be much hurt after it had done bleeding—he said it affected his temple—I saw him in the same house the next morn
ing, and he complained of pain in the temple—his eye was very nearly
closed, and swollen—he had his hand up to his face—I persuaded him to go home to his mother—he was not very tipsy—he was not sober.

WILLIAM MURPHY . I am porter at the University College Hospital, On the 4th of July the deceased was brought there—his head and face ap
peared very much swollen, and particularly the right cheek—there was a small bruise or cut on the right side of his nose—he did not point that out to me—he said something about it.

HENRY BURFORD NORMAN . I am house-surgeon at the University Hospital. On the 15th of July, about twelve o'clock in the day, I saw the deceased—his face was then very much swollen from erysipelas, parti
cularly on the right side—the right eye was almost closed—I saw nothing more than a slight contusion of the eye lid—it was difficult to say How much of the swelling belonged to the blow, and How much was caused by the erysipelas—the whole of the right side of the face was swollen, and it was extending on the left side also—I found that he was a person of drunken habits—I cannot say whether he was then perfectly sober, from the change produced by disease—I talked to him, and he stated he had been struck the day before in the eye, but I did not inquire very particularly into it—he said he had been drinking porter and gin for the last eight or nine days, and she believed he had not eaten a quarter of a loaf in that time, or a quartern loaf—he died on the 19th from erysipelas, which I supposed to be caused by the blow.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You cannot undertake to say that? A. No—erysipelas is a disease very little understood as to its cause—there is no doubt that he died from erysipelas—it will sometimes seize on a person of intemperate habits without any exciting cause, or it may arise from natu
ral causes—it is more likely to arise from an open cut than from a contusion—I did not see him till the 15th—the first surgeon who saw him is not here—I should not say he had delirium tremens, only simple delirium, which is the natural result of intemperate habits—it would be the more likely to result to a man who had had no solid food for eight or ten days—I cannot undertake to say the blow had anything to do with his death.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. I believe erysipelas very frequently follows wounds? A. It does—I saw no cut—it might not be a cut though the skin is broken—if the skin is, abraised it would be likely to be followed by something of this kind—if it should turn out that there had been abrasion of the skin on the 13th, I could not say with confidence that this blow was the cause of death—I cannot say with confidence that the blow was the immediate cause of the erysipelas, but I should be inclined to attribute it to it.

RICHARD QUAIN . I am surgeon at the University College Hospital, and am professor at the College. I saw the deceased on the 15th of July—I saw his body after death—I attributed his death to erysipelas—I can
not state with confidence that the blow on the nose was the cause that produced the death—if I had seen him from the time of his receiving the blow I might have been able to say.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

2445.
ROBERT GERARD was indicted
for feloniously uttering, on the 23rd of August, a forged request for the delivery of goods, with intent to defraud
James Crosier.

JAMES CROSIER . I am an oil and colour man, in Brewer-street, Somers
town. On the 23rd of August, between three and six o'clock in the even
ing, the prisoner came to my shop with this order—he said he had come from a gentleman named Barham, who I had served before—(he had been to me three months before, and those things were sent and paid for)—I asked what things he wanted—he said, "White lead, oil, umber, and ochre, var
nish, and Brunswick green"—I did not let him have the goods—I made out a bill of the things he proposed to have—to the best of my recollection they came to 1l. 13s.—he asked me to give him the bill enclosed in the order—I refused at first, but I thought he might probably want to take it back again, and I wafered it up and gave it him—he said he would call again at six o'clock in the evening, and go with my boy to take the things to Mr. Bar
ham, and my boy was to bring back the money—he said the gentleman was a very nice young man, and had got plenty of money—I told him I gave no credit—after I had given him the bill he asked roe to let him have half-a-crown, as he had got some things to get for the gentleman—he owed me 6s. before, and he said, "When the things are sent up to the gentleman's, your boy shall bring back the money, and I will pay you a trifle of what I owe yon, I shall have some money then"—he came back in an hour or an hour and a half, not sober, to borrow another half-crown—I said, "Gerard, what hare you done with the other half-crown, I am afraid you have been spending it in drink?"—he said, "No, I have not, I am as sober as you are"—I asked him for the bill—he said he had given it to the gentleman at four o'clock—he took his hat off, and the order and the bill fell out—I told him to hand it to me—he refused at first's, but I said, "You had better let me have it, and I shall have something to show"—he then gave it me—I followed my lad with the goods, and found Mr. Barbara at No. 45, Devon shire-street, instead of No. 28—No. 28 is where he formerly resided—I have not got the bill here—it was given to a gentleman in Mr. Braham's house—the policeman has a similar one which was made out—I should have acted on the mere production of die order alone—I should have sent white lead, oil, and trumps, nothing more, had he not given me the order for more—this is a common form of order in the trade—it is in the same form as one I had had previously—he did not ask me to give him the goods, but to make out a list for the gentleman—I called on Mr. Barham the same evening—I did not know him—I saw a gentleman wlip I thought was Mr. Barham, who said it was not his writing—I called next morning, and saw Mr. Barham—I bad the goods close by his door waiting for him, to see they were delivered, on the same evening—I have not got the paper which contained the list of the goods—I made k out—the prisoner was to call for the goods in the evening, but after he called the second time I had some suspicion, and went with them myself—he did not go with me—I saw nothing more of him till he was in custody—he did not pro
pose to take the goods in the first instance—he described what goods he wanted—he said nothing about my giving him anything for bringing the order—I generally gave him something.

HENRY BARHAM . I lived at No. 28, Devon shire-street. On the 23rd of August, when Mr. Crosier called on me, I was living at No. 46—no per
son of my name lives at No. 28 now—I employed the prisoner to do some painting for me about four months ago at No. 28—on that occasion I sent a note to Mr. Crosier for some oil and colours, which came to 30s., I think

—I paid for that on delivery—I afterwards employed the prisoner to paint the front of No. 45—I never saw him since—he once called, but I did not see him—I did not send him with this note—no part of it is my writing, or the writing of any of the parties living at No. 28—two gentlemen, named Brandon, and a servant live there—I always considered the prisoner honest—I was out of town on the day he presented this order, and only came back that evening—it was shortly before I left town that the prisoner called on me—I might have had a little painting to do—I had trusted him to get paint on two former occasions.

JEREMIAH LOCKABY (police-constable S 180.) I took the prisoner into custody in Edmund-street, Battle-bridge, between seven and eight o'clock on the morning of the 25th of August—I said, "Mr. Crosier wishes to speak with you"—he said, "Yes, I know what it is about, I will call as soon as I have had my breakfast"—I said, "You had better go with me now"—he said, "Very well, I will go with you"—on the road he said, "This is a bad job, but I intended calling and paying him the money, I was intoxicated when I did it"—he asked what I thought be would be done to—I said I could not say (order read.)
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
2446.
JAMES FRANCIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of August, 3 candlesticks, value 3s., the goods of
Thomas Morris; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 52.—
Confined Three Months.

2447.
WILLIAM HOPKINS was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of August, 1 pair of boots, value 5s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 3s. 6d.; 1 purse, value 6d.; and 1 shilling; the goods of
James Fossett; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

2448.
WILLIAM GILLETT was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of August, 2 loaves of bread, value 8d., the goods of
William Walter Reynolds; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Ten Days.

2449.
JOHN THOMPSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of August, 5 cushions, value 2l., the goods of
John Houlditch and another; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

2450.
CHARLES HARRIS was indicted
for embezzling, on the 17th of June, 12s. 6d., the monies of
Alexander Grant; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

2451.
GEORGE OSBORN was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of August, 600 yards of cord, value 4s. 1d., the goods of
Joseph Lee; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

2452.
MARY LYONS was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of July, 2 blankets, value 6s.; one looking-glass and frame, value 2s.; 2 flat-irons, value 1s. 6d.; and one bolster, value 5s.; the goods of
Philip Wood:—also,
on the 20th of July, 2 sheets, value 5s.; 2 pillows, value 5s.; 1 blanket, value 2s.; one looking-glass and stand, value 3s.; 1 basin, value 9s.; 1 kettle, value 1s. 4d.; 2 saucepans, value 1s. 9d.; 1 flat-iron, value 8d.; 1 bottle, value 9d.; 3 jugs, value 9d.; 6 plates, value 1s.; 1 dish, value 1s.; 3 cups, value 6d.; 3 saucers, value 6d.; 3 knives, value 9d.; 3 forks, value 9d.; and 2lbs. weight of feathers, va
lue 2s.; the goods of
Joseph Clark; to all which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined One Year.

2453.
WILLIAM SEWELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of August, 1 printed book, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Edward Eedle:—also,
on the 6th of August, 2 printed books, value 5s., the property of
Felix Spon; to both which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Three Months.

2454.
JOHN WINNINGTON was indicted
for feloniously receiving, on the 1st of June, 1500 ermine skins, value 65l., the goods of
George Henry Schacht.
MR. BODKIN conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN CHARLES . I am clerk to George Henry Schacht, a skin merchant in George-street, Mansion-house. Between Saturday 27th, and Monday 29th of November last, his warehouse was broken open, and a large quan
tity of skins stolen—there were 155 bundles of ermine skins lost—they were tied in bundles—there were 25 bunt as of dressed, worth from 37s. to 50s. per timber of 40 skins, and the rest were raw, worth from 35s. to 40s. per timber—there are only three other houses in London which import skins of that sort, I have been fifteen years with Mr. Schacht, and eight years with another merchant—in June last I had information from Ellis and Everington—I went to their shop in St. Paul's Church-yard—I was there shown six and a half timbers of ermine skins—I have no hesitation in laying they were part of those stolen from Mr. Schacht, from their qua
lity—part of them had been in the warehouse nearly three years.

EVAN MEREDITH . I am in the employ of Messrs. Ellis and Ever
ington, of St. Paul's Church-yard. On Saturday, the 18th of June, a per
son named Bull came to our house (he had been in our employ from eight to ten years before), he produced 4 dressed and 4 undressed skins as a sample, and asked if we bought such things—he said he had about 10d. timber of them—he wanted 27s. for the dressed and 25s. for the undressed—I said I must see the bulk—he said he would show me timber dressed, and asked if I would purchase them first, he would show me the others afterwards—having heard of Mr. Scratch's robbery, I made a communica
tion to them, and an appointment was made for Bull to come again, which he did in half an hour, accompanied by the prisoner—they brought these 6) timber of ermine skins—Bull introduced the prisoner to me as the owner of the skins—he told me he was a Sir John Winning ton, who bad made a purchase of them—in consequence of something which had passed between me and Mr. Charles, I went on to buy these timbers for 25s.—this invoice was made out—the prisoner wrote it—I asked for some reference to be given, and a Mr. Bartholomew, of New Inn, was given—the prisoner

and Bull then went away. On Monday the 20th, the prisoner brought a timber of undressed skins—he said that was a sample of 31 timbers, and 25s. was mentioned as the price—I told him I could not buy them unless I saw the whole of them—he went to fetch them immediately—he returned without them, and said he was too late, he could not see the party and be could not bring them that day—an appointment was made that he was to bring them on the 24th of June—in the mean time I received a letter from Bull—after the receipt of it I went to a public-house—I found no one there.—On the 24th of June the prisoner brought 30 timbers of un
dressed—22s. was bargained for as the price of the whole of them—I made him that offer and he accepted it—I proceeded to count the skim, and while they were being counted I sent to Mr. Schacht's place, and Mr. Charles came to the place—he stated in the prisoner's hearing that he be
lieved they were his property and that they were stolen from their pre
mises—the prisoner said they were his property and he would not give account of them—he was then taken into custody—Messrs. Ellis and Everington use these skins in their business—about three persons in London import these skins.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did the prisoner give you his address? A. Yes, No. 34, Elliott-row, Lambeth—I sent to Mr. Bartho
lemew's, and found it was perfectly right—his address was correct—Mr. Oppenheim, Mr. Magnum, and Mr. Schacht, are the only persons that sell ermine skins, that I know of—I have been in the fur trade about fifteen years—Ellis and Everington do not confine themselves to the fur trade—they sell linens and woollens, and other things—we deal very largely in furs—we deal with the three merchants I have mentioned—Sir Wiliam Poland is an importer of skins—I should think last year not above 500 timbers of ermine skins were imported, and about 800 the year before—I can always tell by the imports of the Custom-house.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Have Ellis and Everington a department for skins? A. Yes, and I manage it.

VITRUVIUS WITCOMB . I am warehouseman to the prosecutor. I have examined these thirty-one bundles of skins, and I find some of them to be cut by myself—I have examined them attentively—I am able to swear they are part of my master's stock—I missed them on the Monday after the robbery—I had seen them about a week before—I had had them in my hand about four times.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Will you give us one of these skins that has your own cut on it? A. This is one, they are cut up the belly to see if there are any moth eggs in it—the skins are not cut when they come over here—it is very likely that other persons cut them as well as I when they suspect there are eggs in them—we cut straight down—no two cuts are alike—I know I cut the skins—we have no occasion to cut them, but these being old skins I cut some to see—I do not swear to this one in particular—I cannot say How many cut skins there are in the bundle—I do not cut all—this is a remarkable skin—there is not another like this in the world—it is torn—this skin is damaged—damaged skins are very common—I will swear to this one out of the whole.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Had you noticed this before? A. Yes.
PETER THIRION . I am a fur-skin dresser. I dress for the prosecutor—these skins have been through my hands as a dresser—I sent home five timbers on the Friday previous to the robbery.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you dress a great many in the course of a year? A. Yes, but last year there was very little done—I did but dress these twenty timbers for Mr. Schacht—I dress for five or six persons—there are about four importing houses in the trade—I know these because some of them went in two or three pieces in dressing, being old skins, and I was obliged to put these pieces together again—they passed through my hands three or four times, and went to pieces several times—I do not suppose there ever was such a lot of skins in the trade for these six years.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Is it general in the importing houses to dress them, A. There are two or three retailers who buy and dress them.
MR. BODKIN. or do retailers? them.

FREDERICK' AUGUSTUS SCHROETBB . I am in the employment of Oppenheim and Co., who are importers of these skins—there are only two or three more importers—I have compared some of these skins with skins remaining at Mr. Schachts, and to the best of my belief they are of the same bulk.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. That is a mere speculation? A. This is a very remarkable lot of skins—they are so damaged and stained that I should think that any man who had to do with them might know them.

HENRY SCHACHT . I am an importer of skins of this kind—I have ex
amined these skins, and I have no doubt in my mind that they are my property—these skins are generally bought from the importers by for manufacturers—the value of these undressed skins is from 30s. to 40s. a timber, and the dressed ones about 10s. a timber more.

WILFRED CALLENDER . I am porter to Ellis and Everington. On the 18th of June I was sent to Mr. Schacht with a message—after I had re
turned home the prisoner and Bull came there—when they went out I was desired to follow them, which I did—they went a little way down Ludgate-street, and then turned back, and went a little way along St. Paul's Church-yard, then went back, and went down Dean's-court, across Carter-lane, and down Addle-hill, and into the Bell, where they waited about half-an-hour—they came out, went up Addle-hill, along Shoemaker-row, to the Broadway, Blackfriars, through a court on to Ludgate-hill—they then went about 100 yards, turned back, and came up to Stationers'-hall-court, up Warwick-lane, on to Newgate-market, across the market, through a passage between two public-houses—they went into one public-house, and through into Newgate-street, and there I lost them—when they came out of Ellis and Everington's door there was another person waiting for them, and he went with them to the public-house where they waited half-an-hour, but he did not come out with them.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you go into the house where they waited half-an-hour? A. No, because they had seen me in the warehouse, and they might have known me if I had followed them.
FRANCIS M'CLEAN . I am a police-officer. I took the prisoner into custody at Elliott's-row, Lambeth, in the front attic, which is a small room—there was no warehouse or appearance of business.

GUILTY . Aged 45.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2455.
WILLIAM HOOTON was indicted
for embezzling, 264l. 15s. 10d., the monies of
Charles Pugh and another, his masters; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2456.
JAMES BRIMAGE was indicted
for embezzlement.
MR. BODKIN conducted the Prosecution.

JOSEPH PRICE . I am a coffin furniture manufacturer—my father carried the business on before me to the time of his death, on the 25th of February last—the executors carried it on till the 22nd of March, and on that day I took possession of it on my own account—the prisoner had been in my father's employ, and then I took him at a salary of 30s. a week—it was his duty to carry on business at a house in Compton-street—he conducted that branch of my business—he entered in a book the money he received for things sold, and he had to collect money from persons out of the house, and to enter that separately—he never accounted to me for 9l. 19s. 10d., as received from Mr. Douglas, on the 16th of May, and there is no ac
count of it in the book—he never accounted to me for 4l. 12s. 11d., or 4l. 15s. 9d. as received on the 27th of May, and on the 6th of August of Mr. Butler—in consequence of some other matters, I directed him to be spoken to by Mr. Nonie, on the 15th of August, and he was taken into custody on the 17th.

Cross-examined by MR. CROUCH. Q. How long had he been in the service of your family? A. About four years—it is about four years since he went into that shop in Compton-street—he had been before that in busi
ness for himself, but he had been in my father's employ before that—he was the proprietor of a shop in the same street in which my father after
wards carried on business—it was partly a continuation of the prisoner's business—he was not allowed by my father to carry on business for him
self, to my knowledge—he has drawn bills on persons on our account—he has not been accustomed to do business for himself to my knowledge—the book in which the accounts were kept was in his possession, and it was his duty to come to me to account for the sums received—he usually brought this book with him, and after the settlements of these accounts he kept the book—it has not remained in my custody for some days to my knowledge—he has not complained that he could not get it—I have no recollection of its being left for me to examine—I do not recollect any mistakes with regard to monies not being paid by the prisoner—he was in the habit of selling things for me, but not of buying, certainly.

Q. Has he at no time been ordered to pay money out of what he re
ceived, to persons to whom you were indebted? A. I once told him to pay the rent of the house in Compton-street—I never told him to pay money due by me, to my knowledge—I occasionally call at the house in Compton-street, and I have on one or two of those occasions received cash of him—I do not know whether it was marked down in the book then, but it was on the following Monday—I remember only one instance of receiving money without giving a voucher—I am not aware that I have applied to persons for money after the money has been accounted for to me by the prisoner—I have carried on the business about five months—the two last sums in the indictment are due to myself—part of the first is due to the estate—I certainly never paid the prisoner any portion of the profits on goods sold and delivered—I never discounted bills for him to my remembrance—I gave him cash for one bill—I know Mr. Crow, of Tothill-street—I never discounted bills of his—my business is carried on in the name of Price and Co.—it has been carried on for years in that
way—I nave no partner—I was not in partnership with my father—I superintended the business for him.
WILLIAM DOUGLAS . I am an undertaker, and live in Han way-street. I was indebted to the prosecutor 9l. 19s. 10d.—I paid that to the prisoner in May last—he gave me a receipt on the bill.

HENRY BUTLER . I am an undertaker, and live in High-street, St. Giles's. I am a customer of Mr. Price's—on the 27th of May I paid the prisoner 4l. 12s. 11d. on account of Mr. Price—here is the receipt of it in my book, in his handwriting—on the 6th of August I paid him 4l. 15s. 9d.—here is his receipt to it in the same book, with his name to both.

Cross-examined. Q. To whom were these sums of money owing? A. To Mr. Price—the goods I paid for in May were what I had in April—on the 6th of August the prisoner paid me some money for a few goods that I supplied him with on his own account—he did very little business on his own account, but I have supplied him with things—I do not know whether Mr. Price knew of it—the money I received of the prisoner was 2l. 3s., for some goods that the prisoner had the use of—I never supplied Mr. Price with any goods—I thought it was Price and Son, I did not know.

JOSEPH NORIE . I am foreman to Mr. Price. In consequence of some other transactions, I spoke to the prisoner about his account on the 15th of August—this book of his was before me—I asked him whether it con
tained all the money he had received—he said, "Yes"—I have looked through it to see if it contains these three sums mentioned in this indict
ment—there is no entry of any of them—here is a settlement at the end of the week after the 16th of May, at the end of the week after the 27th of May, and at the end of the week after the 6th of August—there is a ba
lance on the week after the 6th of August, but that does not contain the 4l. 15s. 9d. from Mr. Butler.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you in the habit of settling the book with the prisoner? A. No—I did not go to demand money of the prisoner—I asked him about it—he generally brought the book down on Monday mornings, and took it away with him—I do not recollect one instance when he left it—he has never complained to me about his accounts being irre
gularly kept, to my knowledge—the book was never kept from him, to my knowledge—I had nothing to do with the book—I do not know of any bill transaction between customers of the prisoner and my master—I never knew my master to discount bills for coffin-makers at the instance of the prisoner.

Q. Did the prisoner never mention to you about the irregularity of Mr. Price's accounts? A. He might have said something—he did say some
thing at one time about one trifling thing, but I cannot tell what it was—it was of no consequence—I cannot say whether that was in old Mr. Price's time or young Mr. Price's—I believe the prisoner has taken a house near my master's, on his own responsibility—this case has been got up since we knew that—we never had any suspicion of him previously, but found his accounts regularly kept.

JOSEPH PRICE
re-examined. Q. Do you know of the prisoner having taken a house near your premises? A. Yes, next door—I believe I men
tioned to him that I did not like it—I do not know that I have mentioned it to any one else—I think he has had it about six weeks.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know a Mr. Nodes, of Tottenham Court-road?

A. Yes—I have not had a conversation with him about this house that the prisoner has taken—I do not know that I have mentioned it to any one—I have an indistinct idea that I mentioned it to a friend of mine—I have not watched the prisoner's conduct since he took this house more narrowly than previously.
(John Brown, a furnishing undertaker, in Edgeware-road; Thomas Richards, a costermonger; and Turner, clerk of St. Sepulchre's, gave the prisoner a good character).

GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2457.
ANDREW VALANCE was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of August, 20 pieces of wood, value 3d.; and 2 gauges, value 1i.; the goods of
Joseph Gordon Davis.

GEORGE WEST . I am servant to Joseph Gordon Davis. I was watch
ing his premises on the 11th of August—I saw the prisoner come and pot some pieces of wood into a sack—these are them—(producing some small pieces of chips out of a bag.)
JURY. This ought not to be continued.
NOT GUILTY .

2458.
JOHN SHEPPARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of August, 112lbs. weight of rope, value 8s., the goods of
Thomas Sturge, on a certain quay adjoining to a port of entry and discharge.—2nd COUNT, stating it to be the goods of
Robert Mason.—3rd COUNT, stating it to be the goods of the
East and West India Dock Company.

ROBERT MASON . I am in the service of Thomas Sturge, a ship-keeper—I was ship-keeper to the Diana, in the East and West India Docks,. On the 3rd of August I left some rope on the quay, and some other things—on the 4th the rope was gone—it was Mr. Sturge's—this now produced is it.
JOHN SIMMONS . I am a labourer in the East and West India Docks—I saw this rope on the quay, and the prisoner took it away in a truck.
Prisoner. Q. Was nobody with me? A. Yes, another man, but I do not know him.

THOMAS ROBERTS . On the 4th of August the prisoner came into the Export-dock, and came out with a truck full of rope and shakings—be presented this pass, signed "Robert Burgin," and said he brought it from the baroque Mandingo.

JAMES WILLIAM WILLIAMS . I am the mate of the Mandingo. I did not give this pass to the prisoner—I have seen Captain Burgin about it, and it is all a forgery—it is not like Captain Burgin's writing—nor is it mine.
Prisoner. Two men who enticed me in gave the pass to me; I cannot read or write; he asked the other man, not me.

THOMAS ROBERTS
re-examined. The prisoner was the active person with this pass—he did not tell me the other man gave it him.

Prisoner's Defence. I was standing at the King's Head, Lime house; two men came to me, and asked me to buy some old rope; they said it was in the dock; they got the pass, and I went in with them—I gave them 7s. 6d. for the rope, and gave them a hand to put it into the truck; as we came to the gate, one of them gave me the pass to give it to the officer; we took it out, and sold it for 9s. 6d. at the marine-store shop,
where I have sold many tons of it before; the men then went away; next day I was going by the Dock, and was taken.

GUILTY . Aged 71.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(The prisoner had been convicted of felony six times before).

2459.
JOHN POWER was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of Au
gust, 3 3/4 lbs. weight of bacon, value 2s., the goods of
John Cousins; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

WILLIAM HOMAN . I am shopman to John Cousins, a cheese monger, in Mary-le-bone-lane. On the 19th of August I received information, and ran out—I saw the prisoner with this bacon in his hand—I brought him back—this is my master's bacon—I had seen it safe five minutes before.
Prisoner. You never found it on me. Witness. As soon as I took you threw it down—there were two men in your company.
JOSEPH NIFTON (police-constable D 118.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read) the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2460.
EMMA WHITE was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of Au
gust, 1 hat, value 15s., the goods of
William Bradbeer.

WILLIAM BRADBEEE . I live in Seymour-mews, and am a cab pro
prietor. On the 4th of August I met the prisoner by the Yorkshire Stingo—I went home with her, and gave her money to go for some liquor—she put on my hat, and said she would be back presently—I never saw her again till she was taken this is my hat—there was another woman with her.
Prisoner. You have known me for the last five years. Witness. I have known her—she might have taken it for a lark,
WILLIAM LAWRENCE . This hat was pawned by the prisoner for 5s.
Prisoner. I was there, but did not pawn it.
LAWRENCE ANDERSON (police-constable D 35.) I took the prisoner—I said it was for stealing a hat—she said she knew nothing about it.
Prisoner. Q. Did not the other female own that she pawned it? A. Certainly she did.
NOT GUILTY .

2461.
THOMAS DURDAN was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of August, a bushel of oats, chaff, and beans, value 2s., the goods of
John, Gurney, his master: and
THOMAS DAY
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen.

JAMES BENNETT . I am clerk to Mr. John Gurney, who keeps a brewery at Lambeth—Durdan was his servant, and it was his duty to take out nose-bags of food for his horses. On the 17th of August he went out with one horse, and if he took any corn out, it was his duty to give it to the horse, or to bring it back—the food consisted of oats, chaff, and beans—I received information, and sent for him into the room, and Mr. Gurney asked him if he did not go to Baker's, in Hamilton-row, Bagnigge-wells-road—he said "Yes"—Mr. Gurney said, "Was all right there?"—be said, "Yes, sir"—he said, "Did you take your nose-bag?"—he said, "Yes, sir"—he said, "Did you give the horse the food?"—he said, "Yes, sir"—the policeman who was present then questioned him as to the contents

of the nose-bag, and asked him whether he gave it to the horse, or sold it—he replied, "I am too fond of horses to give away their food, the horse had it"—the policeman said he had been informed he had sold the con
tents of the nose-bag to another man—he said he had not—the policeman said he should take him on the charge—he said he was quite innocent, he had certainly given some away, but no money passed.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did not Mr. Gurney ask him if he had a man to help him? A. Yes, it is allowed that he should hare a man to help him if he goes with a single horse—when I send him out, I desire him to have a man, and to pay him 6d.—he was six weeks in our service.

CLEMENT HINE . On the 17th of August, Durdan agreed with me to help him, and he gave me some beer for my work—when we came from the house be went over and spoke to Day—he then came back to the dray, and unbuckled the nose-bag from the shaft, took it, and emp
tied it into Day's cart—he brought the nose-bag back empty—the pri
soner and another man then went into a public-house and drank—I saw Day change a shilling at the bar.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Before anything occurred with the nose-bag, did not Durdan tell you ought to have put it on the horse? A. Yes, I told him I had nothing to do with that, and he said he must not take it home.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How came you out that day? A. I am in no regular employment—I job for any one—I had never teen Day before—this occurred on a Wednesday—I gave information about it on Friday—I did not see anybody before—I was busy on Thursday—I spoke to Durdan's sister about Day—I did not say I had a spite against Day, but not against Durdan—I said Day ought to know better than to buy it.
HENRY REDMAN (police-constable G 244.) I took Day—he said he did not recollect being in Bagnigge Wells-road at all that Wednesday.
NOT GUILTY .

2462.
JOHN SWEET was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of May, 2 shirts, value 5s.; 12 towels, value 12s.; 6 yards of lawn, value 10s.; and 5 yards of linen cloth, value 5s.—also,
on the 1st of August, 11 shirts, value 3l.; 10 towels, value 10s.; 47 yards of linen cloth, value 3l. 5s.; 4 petticoats, value 4s.; 26 pillow-cases, value 14s.; and 1 bed
gown, value 1s.; the goods of
George Hayter, and others, his masters: to both of which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined Six Months.

2463.
THOMAS CHURCH was indicted
for embezzlement.
HENRY PEARSE . I am the prisoner's master. On the 8th of August I sent him to Mr. Edward Honeyball's with a bill of 18s., to get the money for me—he did not return, nor bring me the bill or money.
EDWARD HONEYBALL . I received the bill, on the 8th of August, from Mr. Pearse—I believe the prisoner brought it—I paid him.
WILLIAM ALDERMAN (police-sergeant H 7.) I took the prisoner—he said the old man might have settled it, meaning his father.
Prisoner. I left my goods on a form while I went to get half a pint of beer, and when I came out they were gone; the bill was with them—
thought, when my master went to my father, he would have settled it; I was afraid to go home.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

2464.
GEORGE TOWNLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of August, 2 gowns, value 1l. 1s; 15 yards of calico, value 10s.; and 1 Spencer, value 9s; the goods of
Catherine Brockly.
CATHERINE BROCKLY . I am a dress-maker, living in Dean-street, Soho; the prisoner came to visit my servant occasionally. On the 16th of August I missed two gowns and the other things stated.
JOHN KENDALL . I am shopman to a pawnbroker. I produce this calico, which was pawned by the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2465.
ANN REYNOLDS was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of July, 1 jacket, value 7s.; and 2lbs. weight of tobacco, value 6s.; the goods of
Charles M'Canna; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

CHARLES M'CANNA . I belong to the ship Montezuma. I met the pri
soner, on the 29th of July, in Blue gate-fields—she wanted me to go with her—I said I had not much money—she said, if I paid her so much I could go—I gave her 3s. 6d., and went to a house, about nine o'clock—I sat there some time, and had some beer—I sat on a chair, took off my jacket, and hung it on the back of the chair—the prisoner took my jacket and' ran off with it—there were two pounds of tobacco in the pocket—I went after her, but there was something of a catch in the door, so that I could not get out—this is my jacket.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. You had known her some time? A. Not more than a month—I went backwards and forwards to her place—I have never been there without money—I visited her before I got my pay
note—I had money when I received my note—I never told her I was asham
ed to see her, as I had no money—I once showed her my monthly money-note—she took it from me—I rushed upon her and got it from her, and it was so torn that I was forced to get another—she asked me if I was going to sea again—I said yes, when she took the jacket and rushed out, and I saw no more of her till she came in the next morning—I said I would give her in charge, and her mother wanted to turn me out of the house, but I would not go—I did not agree to take 5s.—nobody offered me 5s.
THOMAS JOHN SHUTE . I am a pawnbroker. This jacket was pawned by the prisoner, between seven and eight o'clock in the morning, on the, 30th of July.

THOMAS HENRY ELLIS (police-constable K 303.) I produce a certifi
cate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2466.
JOSEPH FRITCHLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of August, 1 wheel, value 6s. 6d. the goods of
Peregrine Peck.

PEREGRINE PECK . I live in Queen-street, Seven-dials. I returned home, on the 13th of August, and found a wheel gone—this now produced is it—I know the prisoner only by his loitering about the street.
ROBERT BEECH . I live in Crown-place, Solo. I had bought this wheel of my father to sell again—I repaired it and sold it to Mr. Peck—on the

13th of August the prisoner came to my shop—he brought this wheel, and asked me if I would buy it—I asked him what he wanted for it—he said 3s.—I told him, if he would come in an hour, I might be able to buy it; and then I went to Mr. Peck.
Prisoner's Defence. A man met me in Queen-street; he asked me to sell it.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

2467.
WILLIAM PRICE and
ALEXANDER DUNCAN were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August, 2 pairs of shoes, value 5s., the goods of
Sarah Ann Silverside and another.

JANE SILVERSIDE . I keep a shop with my sister Sarah Ann Silverside, in Clerkenwell. On the 18th of August I saw the two prisoners near the door, and soon afterwards I saw them go away—I got up and missed two pairs of shoes—I saw the prisoners running—one of them dropped the shoes—I took them up—they are ours.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Are you sure Duncan was one of them? A. Yes.

CHARLES DENIS . I heard a cry of "Stop thief," and saw the two pri
soners running—Duncan threw down these shoes—I stopped him—he said he had nothing to do with the shoes.
Price's Defence. I know nothing about them; I was not with Duncan when they were taken.

PRICE*—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Transported for Seven Years—Convict Ship.

DUNCAN—
GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined One Month, the last Week Solitary, and
Whipped.

2468.
CATHERINE KELLY was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of August, 1 pewter pot, value 1s., the goods of
Thomas Evan Gamble.
WILLIAM HAYNES . I live with Thomas Evan Gamble, a publican. This is his pot—the prisoner came to the shop, on the 11th of August, and had a pint of beer there.

THOMAS WELLS (police-constable E 180.) I saw the prisoner in Ox
ford-market, picking bones and rags—she had this pot in her basket.
Prisoner. I had had a pint of beer, and was going to take the pot back. Witness. She was a mile and a half from Mr. Gamble's.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Three Months.

2469.
JOHN ROBINSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of August, 1 necklace, value 7s., the goods of
Elizabeth Way, from her person.

ELIZABETH WAY . I am fifteen years old. I was going along Sun-street, Bishopsgate-street, on the 3rd of August—I had a necklace round my neck—two boys came to me—the prisoner was one of them—he came behind me, took off my necklace, and ran away—I am sure he is the person.
WILLIAM HORLEY (police-constable G 172.) I took the prisoner, from the description the prosecutrix gave at the station.

GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Transported for Ten Years.—Convict Ship.

2470.
JAMES M'ALLEN and
DENNIS HARRINGTON were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August, 6lbs. weight of beef, value 3s. the goods of
Richard Kifford.

HENRY DORCHESTER . I live in Harrison's-court, Ratcliffe. On Satur
day night, the 13th of August, I was at Richard Kifford's shop at Shad
well—I saw the prisoners coming by the shop—M'Allen took some beef off the block and put it under his jacket—Harrington was with him—they went as far as the Coach and Horses—I ran and asked them for the beef—M'Allen dropped it—I picked it up.
THOMAS SHEPHERD . I am servant to Mr. Richard Kifford. I missed the beef from outside the shop.
JAMES ROOKE (police-constable K 245.) I went to the Coach and Horses—I saw the prisoners—M'Allen was drunk—I charged them with taking the beef—they said they knew nothing of it.
Harrington's Defence. M'Allen asked me to go and have a pint of beer; the officer laid hold of him; I said, "What do you want with him?" he said I want you too; "I know nothing about it."

M'ALLEN*—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

HARRINGTON*—
GUILTY . Aged 28.
confined Three Months.

2471.
JOHN M'CARTHY was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of August, 19 lbs. of bread, value 3s.; the goods of
John Caswell.

EDWARD CATTAN . I am apprentice to John Caswell, of York-terrace, Stepney. I went out to deliver bread on the 11th of August—I received information, went after the prisoner, overtook him, and found he had got four quartern loaves and two half-quartern—I asked whose bread he had got—he said, his own—I asked where he got it—he made no answer, but put it down, and went off—I gave him into custody—they were my master's loaves.

THOMAS STEWART . I was crossing Whitehorse-street—I saw the pri
soner take the loaves out of the barrow, put them on the lid, shut it down, take the loaves in his arms, and walk off.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined One Month.

2472.
JOHN CARR was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of August, 2 1/2 lbs. weight of bacon, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Joseph Mason.

CHARLES CHRISTIAN MASON . I am in the employ of my father, Joseph Mason. On the 23rd of August, I saw the prisoner and another boy come up together—the other took the bacon—the other stopped against the stall—the prisoner ran up Bun hill-row, and was doubling something up—I took him, with the bacon.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

2473.
REBECCA ROSENBROCK and
MARY CANTILLOW were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August, 120 halfpence, the monies of
John Taylor Foster.

ELIZABETH FOSTER . I am the wife of John Taylor Foster, and live in St. George's-in-the-East. On the 11th of August, I heard a knock at the door—I opened it, and Rosen Brock appeared—she asked for herself and Cantillow to go into the yard—I said they could not, because my landlady was at breakfast, and they would have to go through her room—I told them to come to my room, which they did—while they were there my little boy brought in change for a sovereign, and gave it to me—I had the silver and half-sovereign in my hand—a five-shilling paper of halfpence laid on the table—I removed it from the front of the table to the back part—Cantillow

then wished me to have something to drink, for my kindness in allowing them to come in—I refused, but she insisted on it, and my little boy got a quartern of gin—Rosen Brock took one glass and gave me one—Cantillow had none—I very soon became insensible, and when J came to my senses my five-shilling paper of halfpence was gone, and the prisoners too—I could drink a quartern of gin without being drunk.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How long had you been drinking? A. I had drank nothing before that—I saw Rosen Brock pour out the gin—she took it out of the same glass that I did.
COURT. Q. Was there time for any body to put anything into the glass? A. Yes—I have taken gin before—it never had this effect on me.

JOHN TAYLOR FOSTER , Jun. I remember my brother bringing in the gin—I was sent on another errand, and Rosen Brock told me to make haste, and they would stop till I came back—I returned in a quarter of an hour—the prisoners were then gone, and my mother was stupefied.

Cross-examined. Q. How long had they been in the house? A. From half an hour to three quarters—there was a good deal of conversation—Mr. Lazarus sent to my mother for some shirts, which ought to have gone in that morning.
HENRY HATTON (police-constable H 43.) I took Cantillow—Rosen-brock was on the other side of the road, and was quite drunk—Cantillow was quite sober—she had six pennyworth of copper on her.
ROBERT COLLINS . The little boy came to me for change fore sovereign, and I sent back five shillings in copper.

2474.
SARAH PETO was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of August, 1 shawl, value 2s. 6d.; 5 shillings, 2 sixpences, 2 pence, and 1 halfpenny; the property of
Exsuperious Turner.—2nd COUNT, stating it to be the property of
Ann Turner.

ANN TURNER . I am the wife of Exsuperious Turner, and live in Ironmonger-row, St. Luke. On Tuesday morning, the 16th of August, I met the prisoner in Old-street—I asked her home with me—she went, and I fell asleep on the bed—I left the shawl and money on the mantel-piece—when I awoke she was gone—this is my shawl—no one else was there.
ELIZABETH BELLAMY . Mrs. Turner sent me to get a shawl out of pawn—when I brought it back, the prisoner and Mrs. Turner were asleep—I gave the shawl to the prisoner and twopence-halfpenny.
CHARLES UNDERHILL . I am assistant to James Thomas Hawes, a pawnbroker, in Old-street—this shawl was pawned, in the name of Andrews, on the 16th of August.
NOT GUILTY .

2475.
CHRISTIAN SWANSEA was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of August, 1 pewter pot, value 1s.; the goods of
James Buckmaster.

JOHN PRIOR . I am waiter in the service of James Buck master, who keeps the Swan Tavern, Hunger ford-market—the prisoner came there for a pint of porter and a short pipe, between six and seven o'clock, on the 18th of August—I suspected, and followed him out of the market—he came back, and as he was taking the pot from his pocket, I took it from his hand—it is my master's.
Prisoner's Defence. Prior came and asked for a pot; I said I had left it outside; I came back, took it off the form and showed it him, and he said I took it out of my pocket.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Three Months.

2476.
MARY COLEMAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of August, 6s. oz. weight of bacon, value 5 1/2.; the goods of
Edward John Davey.

FRANCIS DAVEY . I live with my brother, Edward John Davey, in Rochester-row, Westminster—the prisoner was in our shop on the 26th of August, and bought some bacon—I missed something—when she was brought back she threw this other piece of bacon down the area—I am sure I saw her do it—it is my brother's.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined One Month.

2477.
CHARLES SHAW was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of August, 1 pair of trousers, value 4s.; the goods of
William Skinner and another.

GEORGE FRANKS . I am in the employ of William Skinner and his brother, in St. Martin's-court, Leicester-square—I was outside their shop on the 19th of August—I saw the prisoner come up to the shop window and place a pair of trousers under his coat—he went a few yards from the door—I caught hold of him and took him back—he had the trousers under his coat—he laid them on the counter.
JOHN CASTLE WALLER . I saw the prisoner brought back and these trousers were in his breast.
Prisoner's Defence. I was not away from the shop.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

2478.
JAMES COUCH was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of August, 7 yards of oil cloth, value 18s., the goods of
John Taylor.

JOHN THOMAS TOWNSEND . I am servant to John Taylor, of St. John-street-road, Clerkenwell. On the 19th of August, I was going out of the shop, and saw the prisoner just in the act of going off with a piece of floor-cloth—he had got it on his shoulder—some one saw me, and called out Bill—the prisoner dropped it—I ran and took him, and gave him in charge.
JOHN DAVIES being called on his recognizance's, did not appear.
(The prisoner received a good character).

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

2479.
JOHN GUNN and
TIMOTHY SULLIVAN were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August, 5s. lbs. weight of copper, value 3s., the goods of
Robert Tippler, in a vessel in a port of entry and discharge.

ISAAC ANDERSON . I am mate of the brig Scotsman—she was lying in the West India Dock—we lost one sheet of copper from there be
longing to Robert Tipler, the owner.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLASTING. Q. Is he the Captain? A. No—he lives in Tower-street—he is the sole owner of the ship.

WILLIAM ROBERT STEVENSON . I am a wharfinger at the West India Docks. About the 19th or 20th of August, from information I received I watched the two prisoners—I saw them together in conversation for about a quarter of

an hour—they then went to the bow of the Scotsman—Gunn went on board, and went into the galley—he took up something, undid his trousers, pulled up his shirt, and seemed to arrange the parcel—Sullivan was standing on the shore—he put his hand to his mouth, and said something in Irish which caused Gunn to hurry on shore—he very nearly fell into the water—they went on to the gate, and I gave information—when Gunn got about twenty or thirty yards he threw something into the water, and ran off, we pursued and took him—we searched where he threw something, and found this bundle of copper.
ISAAC ANDERSON . I can swear to this—it went round the cook's cabin fire.
JOHN RATTRAY . I am a constable. Stevenson gave me information, and I found this copper in the water.
FREDERICK RUNCIMAN . I am apprentice to Mr. Tippler. I never knew of his having any partners.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

GUNN—
GUILTY . Aged 29.

SULLIVAN—
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Confined Three Months.

2480.
MARY REECE was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Au
gust, 10 1/2 yards of printed cotton, value 8s. 6d., the goods of
George Frederick Butcher.
The article being cheni luster, and not printed cotton, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED ,

2481.
MARY ASHWELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of August, I half-crown, 2 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
Thomas Jones, from his person.

THOMAS JONES . I live in Richmond-street, Lisson-grove. About one o'clock in the morning of the 21st of August, I was coming out of the Crown, at the corner of the Uxbridge-road, and met the prisoner—I said to her, "Will you have a glass of rum?"—she said no, she would rather have the money—we then went down the Uxbridge-road to an
other house—I said, "I will give you sixpence, and will go and have a glass myself"—I came out, and we went down the road—I felt her hand in my pocket—I had one half-crown and two shillings in my right hand pocket—I said, "If you don't give me that money, I will give you in charge"—she said she had nothing of the sort, only the two pence and six
pence—I got the officer, and she was searched—a half-crown and two sixpences were found on her.
Prisoner. You asked me to go to a house with you, I said I would not. Witness. I did not.

WILLIAM BUTCHER (police-constable D 133.) I was called, and took the prisoner—she said she had but sixpence about her—when she got to the station she took out the half-crown, two shillings, and two sixpences.
Prisoner. I told him what money I had, and it was my own.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

2482.
EMMA CLARK was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of August, 9 yards of printed cotton, value 3s. 3d.; 2 yards of woolen cloth, value 1s.; and 3/4 of a yard of lawn, value 7s.; the goods of
Sarah Avila.
WILLIAM BRYANT . I am salesman to Mrs. Sarah Avila. On the 13th

of August the prisoner came to the shop—having suspicion I went to a hole and watched—I saw her take this cloth, lawn and print, and put them into a basket—I got an officer, and she threw them out of the basket on the floor.
Prisoners Defence. I had not got them in my basket.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Four Months.

2483.
HANNAH MAHONEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of August, 1 jacket, value 5s; the goods of
William Crockford.

WILLIAM CROCKFORD . I am apprentice, on board the British Monarch, lying in the West India Docks. I met the prisoner on the 20th of August in Ratcliffe-highway—I gave her 1s. 6d. to go with her—she took me to a house in Blue gate-fields—I put my jacket on the bed—when I awoke it was gone—I asked the prisoner where it was—she said she had pawned it for 2s.—I told her to get it, and she began to abuse me—this now produced is it.
THOMAS JAMES SHUTS . I am shopman to a pawnbroker. This jacket was pawned on the morning of the 20th of August, by a female.
Prisoner. It was not me that pawned it.
GEORGE SWADEN (police-constable K 92.) I took the prisoner—she said she had not pawned the jacket—this is my signature to this deposition—I cannot read it.

COURT. Q. Did you tell the Magistrate this, "I took the prisoner on this 'charge; she said she pawned the jacket, and he had given her no money?" A. I did say those words, and what I said was correct—I did not think for the moment what I was saying just now.
NOT GUILTY .

2484.
WILLIAM FREEMAN and
JOHN WALKER were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August, 1 shawl, value 5s.; the goods of
Mary Jane Brown, from her person.

MARY JANE BROWN . I am single, and live in Tottenham-place, Tot
tenham Court-road. I am a servant, and was on my way home about two o'clock in the morning, on the 20th of August—I sat down, and went to sleep—the policeman awoke me—I saw an empty cab standing in a gate
way—I got into it, and went to sleep—I was awoke by Freeman pulling my shawl—he pulled it off my shoulder—Walker, who was with him, received the shawl, and put it under his smock-frock—I told Freeman, if he wanted sixpence for a bit of bread, I would willingly give it him, but not to distress me by taking my shawl—this is it.

CORNELIUS SAVORY . I am a policeman. I saw the prosecutrix sitting on the steps of a public-house—I awoke her—I saw her again about four o'clock—she was crying, and said she had lost her shawl—(she had it on when I first saw her)—I afterwards saw the prisoners pass—I took them to the prosecutrix, and said, "Are these like the men?"—she said, "Yes, I believe these are the men"—I found this shawl on Walker.
Freeman. I picked it up.
Walker. We found it as we came from the lock.

FREEMAN—
GUILTY . Aged 27.

WALKER—
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Confined One Year.

2485.
ROBERT ELDRIDGE was indicted
for embezzlement.

BENJAMIN HAYES . I live in Gascoyne-place, Hackney-road. The prisoner was in my service—I gave him a bill of parcels on the 20th of August, to receive some money—he paid me 10s., as received from Mr. Purkis, and said that was all he had received.

WILLIAM HENRY PURKIS . I live in Great Distaff-lane. I deal with the prosecutor—on the 20th of August the prisoner came to me, and I paid him a sovereign, a crown-piece, and two half-crowns—the bill is 35s., but the goods came in late, and I paid only 30s., and left the 5s. till I had examined them.
Prisoner. He only gave me a five-shilling piece and two half-crowns.

2486.
JOHN FREDERICK CHURCH,
JULIA CLARA MILLER , and
MARY COLLINS , were indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of July, 2 blankets, value 10s.; 3 sheets, value 10s.; 2 pillows, value 4s.; and I bolster, value 6s.; the goods of
Catherine Breeze.

CATHERINE BREEZE . I live at Westminster. Miller took a furnished room of me, and left without notice—Collins came constantly to her—I missed two blankets, three sheets, and a bolster—some of the articles are here, and are mine.

Miller. You said you would not hurt me if I got them out in a fort
night. Witness. No, I did not.
ALFRED BURBIDGE . I am a pawnbroker. I have a blanket pawned, for 1s. 6d., by a female, in the name of Miller—I cannot say who.
HENRY HALL . I am a pawnbroker. I have two pillows pawned with me by Miller.

JAMES SKELTON (police-constable B 94.) I took Church and Miller—they cohabit together—Miller said she had pawned the things, and she gave me the duplicates—Church said he was as bad as her, and was willing to suffer with her.
NOT GUILTY .

2487.
JULIA CLARA MILLER and
MARY COLLINS were again indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July, 2 sheets, value 10s.; 2 blankets, value 10s.; 1 pillow and case, value 4s.; and 1 basket, value 1s.; the goods of
Joseph Beauchamp.

LUCY CAROLINE BEAUCHAMP . I am the wife of Joseph Beauchamp, and live in Margaret-street, Westminster. On the 16th of July the pri
soners took a furnished lodging of me—I lost the articles stated—this pillow and blankets are mine.
CAROLINE RAYMOND . I was in Mr. Need's, a pawnbroker's shop, in the Westminster-road—Miller came in, and brought these two blankets—she asked me to pass them over for her, which I did.
HENRY HALL . I am a pawnbroker. I produce these blankets, which were pawned by Raymond.
JAMES SKELTON . I am a pawnbroker. I have two blankets, pawned by Miller.

MILLER—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

COLLINS—
NOT GUILTY .
Sixth Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

2488.
MARY ANN MILLS was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of August, 1 painting and frame, value 3l., the goods of
Sigismund Gans.
SIGISMUND GANS . I am a tobacconist, and live in Co vent-garden—the prisoner was my servant. On the 11th of August I missed a picture after eight o'clock at night—this now produced is it.

RICHARD WHITEHEAD (police-constable F 53.) I took the prisoner last Saturday—I told Her it was for stealing a painting from her last master, Mr. Gans, in Bow-street—she said, "I don't know any thing about it"—I found the painting, pawned at Mr. Sean's.

RICHARD SAVER . I am in the service of James Sears, a pawnbroker, in Drury-lane. Between eight and nine o'clock at night, on the 11th of Au
gust, I took this picture in pledge of the prisoner—I am sure it was her.
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the picture; I went to see Mrs. Gans, to get a character, the day before he lost the picture.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

2489.
MARY OAKES and
CATHERINE DANIELS were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July, 1 gown, value 2s.; the goods of
William Farrell.

JULIA FARRELL . I am the wife of William Farrell. On the 26th of July I was sitting at my stall, in High-street, Shad well—the two prisoners came and spoke to me—Daniels asked me for three pence—I told her I had not three pence to lend her—she said she would soon go home and raise sixpence—she said to Oakes, "Come on, Mrs., Oakes, I will soon raise a tanner" which means sixpence—they both went away together—they were not with me above four or five minutes—I went home, and missed my gown, which was hanging in "my room a quarter of an hour before—this now produced is it—Daniels lives in the same house, and Oakes next door.
Daniels. Q. Was I ever inside your door more than once in my life? A. I cannot say—the house is let out in tenements.

MARTHA ANN BROWN . I live in the same room as Farrell—Daniels lived in the house. On the day this gown was lost I saw the prisoners come into the passage together—they went out together—Daniels then had something in her apron—shortly after Mrs. Farrell came home, and made a complaint—when the prisoners came into the house, they told Mrs. Farrell's boy to mind her child—the boy and child went into the yard—I did not see either of them go to Mrs. Farrell's apartments.

THOMAS WALKER . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Waterloo-terrace, Commercial-road. This gown was pawned on the 26th of July, by Oakes, in the name of Smith—I am sure of her—I did not know her before—it was applied for on the following morning—Daniels was not with her.

JAMES MALIN (police-constable K 99.) I took the prisoners—I asked what they knew about the gown—they said, "We know nothing about it, we have been helping a friend to. move"—Daniels had a fender in her hand, and was very obstinate.
NOT GUILTY .

2490.
WILLIAM MARTIN was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of August, 120 halfpence, the monies of
Joseph Mallett and another, his masters.

JOSEPH MALLETT . I am a congreve-match manufacturer—the prisoner was my porter. About ten o'clock in the morning of the 13th of August, I sent him out—after he was gone I had something told me, and I went to the place in my factory where I kept my money—I missed one of two five-shilling packets of halfpence, which were safe about five minutes before—I followed him, and said, "If you will give me back the five-shill lings-worth of halfpence, nobody shall know anything about it"—he said he had got nothing—I told him to go back to the factory, to justify him
self—I saw him go to the factory—he came back again, and said he had cleared himself with my partner, and would go on with my goods—I said, "Have you found the five shillings?"—he said, "It is not found"—I followed him with my eye to a little house, before you arrive at the factory—I saw him put his hand into his pocket—then he came back to me—I said I would not let him go with my goods—he left my goods, and went away—he came back on Monday morning—I have since seen the packet of copper.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Why did not you put a stop to this, by searching him at the time? A. I did not know I was allowed—he has never been searched—the officer took him on the Tuesday—he came for his wages on the Monday—I did not pay him—he came again on Tuesday for his wages—I did not pay him—I owed him 2s. 9d.—he had 7s. a week—no victuals or clothes—he used to work from six o'clock in the morning to seven at night.
NOT GUILTY .

2491.
JAMES M'CULLOCK was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of August, 16 yards of oil-cloth, value 2l. 8s., the goods of
William Element and another.

FRANCIS WILLIAM HALL . I am in the employ of William Element and Mr. Knight, carpet manufacturers, in Holborn. On the evening of the 24th of August, I saw the prisoner and another man at the shop-door, standing talking, one on one side, and one on the other—the other said, "As you like," and then they lifted the roll of cloth on the prisoner's shoulder—he walked up Holborn—the other one went away—the oil
cloth had been inside the door—I followed the prisoner about twenty yards, and asked him to stop with the cloth, as it was not his—he said a gentleman' asked him to take it to Oxford-street, and said he would give him 1s.—I called my master, who took him into the shop, and gave him to a policeman—this is the cloth—it is Mr. Element's and his partner's.

FRANCIS MORRIS (police-constable E 78.) I took the prisoner—Mr. Element said, "Take this man for stealing the oil-cloth"—I said, "You must go with me to the station"—he said, "Very well"—in going, he said, "This is the way an innocent man gets taken"—that was all he said to me.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did he not say a man employed him to carry it? A. He said that to Mr. Element.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Three Months.

2492.
MARY BROWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of Au
gust, 1 shawl, value 5s., the goods of
Richard Thornton Perkins; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

JOSEPH BURGOYNE . I am assistant to Richard Thornton Perkins, a pawnbroker, at Chelsea. On the 6th of August, about five minutes be
fore one o'clock, I saw the prisoner at the counter—I asked what she wanted—she said, Nothing, she was only standing out of the rain—I said, "Very well, we don't charge anything for that"—I walked to the end of the shop—I returned, and missed her, and the shawl which had been hanging about three yards from the door, inside the shop—it had done raining when I first spoke to her—she was only in the shop two minutes after I spoke to her—I went after her—she went into a public-house eight or ten doors off—I followed her—she turned rather pale—I said to the bar-man, "Will you detain this woman a minute?"—she ran out of the other door—I saw the shawl concealed between herself and her child—she ran round Sloane-square—this is the shawl.
CHARLES WRIGHT . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner, and took the shawl from between her person and the child—she said what a fool the was that she did not give it up.

Prisoner's Defence. I went into the shop, and the shawl was down by the side of me; a woman came in, and I thought she might have dropped it; I took it, and walked out with it; I was very much in distress at the time.

GEORGE BEST . I am a policeman. I produce a certificate of the pri
sonar's former conviction, which I got from the office of the clerk of the peace at Westminster—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Four Months.

2493.
RICHARD SAUNDERS was indicted
for embezzlement.

EDWARD BAXTER . I am a grocer, in Cromer-street—the prisoner was my porter, to take out things, and receive-money—on Friday the 22nd of July, I sent him with some goods to Mr. Howard, of Little Windmill-street—the bill was 2l. 14s. 6 3/4 d.—I sent it with them, and he was to re
ceive the money—he ought to have accounted to me for it when he came back, but he never did—I spoke to him about it on the Saturday week fol
lowing, (he never said anything to me in the interim)—he then said he was very sorry, and he would make it up—since he has been committed, his father has paid a portion of the money, which I understand I should not have taken—before his father called, I did not treat it as a debt—it was nine days before the father called on me.
Prisoner. Q. Have you not received twice 5s.? A. Yes, I have—this is my handwriting.

EDWARD HOWARD . I live in Windmill-street, Golden-square. On the. 22nd of July the prisoner brought me some goods from the prosecutor, and this bill with them—I paid him 2l. 13s. on his master's account.
JOHN MURRAY . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner—he said, "He promised to make it all square with Mr. Baxter."

GUILTY. Aged 23.—Recommended to mercy .—
Confined Four Months.

2494.
SAMUEL TAYLOR was indicted
for bigamy.

GEORGE YARROW . I am parish-clerk of St. Leonard, Shoreditch. I produce the register of marriages at that church—I find an entry of a mar
riage—(reads)—" Samuel Taylor, of this parish, bachelor, and Mary Ann Weaver, of this parish, married by banns, this 5th of July, 1835, by me, Thomas Williams"—I was the attesting witness, but I cannot say who were the parties.

CAROLINE BUTLER . I knew the prisoner between three and four months before I was married to—him, which was on the 11th of July last, at Hackney church—I was single—he represented himself as a single man—he said he never went inside of a church before with any woman to be married—my mother and father were present at the wedding.

JOHN SUTHERLAND . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner—he was charged by Butler with bigamy—a woman came with me to the station—I should know her again if I saw her—she stated" she was his lawful wife—I asked him if she was his wife—he said yes—I have not seen her since—he said he married her seven years ago, at Shoreditch church—I said, surely he knew he was doing wrong in marrying a second wife—he said no, as he caught her in bed with another man—that he went to her, and told her that he was to be married, and she said he might do as he pleased.
Prisoner. I never stated any such thing; I never said I was married to her seven years ago. Witness. He said he was married to her seven years ago, at Shoreditch church.

WILLIAM YEOMAN . I am a policeman. I have a copy of a marriage register from St. John's, at Hackney—I got it from the minister of the parish—I compared it with the book—it is signed—(read)—"1842, mar
riage solemnised at St. John's, Hackney, Middlesex, July 11th. Samuel Taylor, bachelor, and Caroline Butler, spinster, were married in this church, after banns, by me, JOHN GRAHAM."
JANE BUTLER . I am Caroline Butler's mother, and was present at her marriage to the prisoner.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not pay for the wedding? A. Yes, because you said you had no money.

Prisoner's Defence. I fell in with her when she was four months in the family way; she asked me to marry her; I told her no; I said I had not got the means, and she said, In my situation, if my father could get any body to marry me he would pay all the expenses"—they wish to send me away, because the father of the child is out of the country; she was mar
ried to him; the child belongs to him; I never wanted the woman.

CAROLINE BUTLER
re-examined. It is false—on the 20th of July his wife came, and turned me out of doors, and took possession of the place the prisoner was there.

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Confined Three Months.

2495.
ELIZABETH M'GILLIVRAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of August, 1 brooch, value 7s.; 1 pair of earrings, value 5s.; and, 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; the goods of
Edmund Stansbury Brotherton; and 3 sovereigns, and 1 half-sovereign, the property of
Ann Lake, her mistress.
ANN LAKE . I am a widow, and live in Thavies-inn. The prisoner was in my service—on the 2nd of August I was at the Isle of Wight—Mrs. Brother son, my daughter, was in charge of my house.

JANE PETERS BROTHERSON . I am the wife of Edmund Stansbury Brotherson. I missed two sovereigns and four shillings out of my work
table drawer, on the 2nd of August, and in consequence of suspicions, I discharged the prisoner—I accused her of it—she said she had taken it out of the drawer—after she was gone I made up my accounts, and missed 3l. 10s. from the scrutoire-drawer in the bed-room—I have since missed a brooch, some earrings, and a handkerchief—these are them.

CHARLES TILLY (City police-constable, No. 296.) I took the prisoner on Saturday week at Mrs. Lake's—I went to the prisoner's lodgings—she directed me there—I found the brooch and earrings, a sovereign, and a handkerchief—in going to Guildhall, she told me she took the earrings and brooch to go to Greenwich—she owned to taking the 2l. 4s., but denied all knowledge of the 3l. 10s.
Prisoner. I did not take the three sovereigns and a half.

GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined Six Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2496.
JAMES FRAZER and
JOHN ADAMS were indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July, 4 loaves of bread, value 1s. 4s.; the goods of
Joseph Simpson, the master of Fraser.

JOSEPH SIMPSON . I keep a baker's shop at Islington. On the 31st of July, I was going home—as I was near home I saw Adams stooping down to my area—I crossed the street, and then saw him stoop down several times—at last he got a 4lb. loaf out of the area—I suppose some one gave it him, as he could not reach—it from the ground—I then saw a parcel in a handkerchief come up in the same way out of the area—he then put them on his left arm, and went across the road—I went to him, and said, I thought he had some of my property—he said he had not, he got it at the West end of the town—I took him back to the shop—I then opened the parcel, and found it contained two 2lbs. loaves, which belonged to me, and so did the other loaf which he had—I had gone out that evening about seven o'clock, and the loaves were then in my bread-bin in the shop—I had left my servant-girl at home—when I got back she was there—I sent her for a policeman—I then called Frazer, who was my man, up from the bake house—I told him there was a person outside wanted him—he came up, and said, "Who wants me?"—I said, "That person at the door"—that was the policeman—I gave him into custody—Frazer was rather in liquor—there was a Miss Brown, a lodger, in my house.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. There was nobody in the house but the servant and a lodger? A. No, not when I went out—I never allowed Frazer a set-off for bread—I occasionally buy bread of some neighbours—this happened on Sunday night the 31st of July—I had not on the Saturday before sent Frazer to a neighbouring shop to buy a quantity of loaves for me—I swear that—I know Mr. Dobell, a baker, in White Lion-street, Pentonville—I did not send Frazer there on that Satur
day, to my knowledge—he might have bought a few stale loaves on my account—we did not want any new loaves—I do not think I sent him to buy any loaves—I am positive I did not—I cannot swear that he did not go to Mr. Dobell's for a loaf, but I did not send him—he has had dealings on my account at Mr. Dobell's—I do not know that he had on his own account—he used to sleep in my house sometimes—my shop is always closed on a Sunday, but we sell a loaf to a customer.

ANN BIRCH . I am the prosecutor's servant—my master and mistress were out on Sunday evening the 31st of July—I was left in charge of the house—there was no one there but me, and Miss Brown in the first-floor—a customer came for bread after my master was gone out—I served it from the bin—there were then 2lbs. and 41bs. loaves in the bin—I do not know How many, perhaps half a dozen of each—Frazer worked for my—master—I let him in that evening about nine o'clock to his work—he
