writing—he seldom saw me write—I signed my name to my deposition—I did not authorise this acceptance to be written—there is property in the bands of the Accountant General, coming to my daughter when she is of age—it falls to the family in consequence of the death of the mother, two years and a half ago—I never employed my daughter or any body to write for me, or sign my name for me—I never put my hand to an acceptance without taking the bill up—my son had not applied to me to accept any such bill—(looking at the copy of the bill)—I had no communication with my son about that paper, that I positively swear—he never had any com
munication with me whatever on the subject of my accepting such a bill—I know nothing of my daughter having the bill—I do not know where my daughter is now—she has been away from me three or four weeks—she left me two or three weeks after this charge was made against the prisoner—I did not take her before the Magistrate—I knew nothing of her going away—I have not heard from her since—I have every reason to believe that she is in the country with a son of mine at Dagenham—if I had been aware she would be wanted she should have been here with me, but I was not—I am not aware that I have been asked many times for her—I believe Mr. Most has called, and he wanted her.

WILLIAM LAPWORTH (police-sergeant K 22.) I took a constable with me to apprehend the prisoner, and took him to the station—I found on him several bills that have not been negociated, but nothing connected with this case—the bill in question, the copy, and the agreement were handed over to me at Lambeth-street, by the Magistrate's wish, and I have pro
duced them—I believe the daughter is kept out of the way—I endea
voured first of all to apprehend her—I afterwards thought it would answer the purpose to summons her as a witness, but I have not been able to find her—I have applied for her attendance, and used every effort—I have not asked the father for her—the clerk at Lambeth-street said the father was not bound to produce her—I have used every other means to produce her—I went to the father's house for her.

JAMES ALSFORD
re-examined. The body of this agreement is the pri
soner's writing—I saw him write it—I do not know that he was drunk when he wrote it—he dictated it himself—I signed it first.

HENRY MILSTSD . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner in charge at the Commercial Coffee-house, London-road—I went up stairs, and knocked at the door—he opened it—I said, "Your name is Layel?"—he said yes—I said, "I am come to take you into custody for forging a bill of 300l."—he said, "Well, I suppose it is all over with me now," or "this time"—he put on his clothes, and went with me—before the Magistrate he denied having said this—he had been in custody before, but not of me; my sergeant had him, and I was with him when he apprehended him.

J. S. MOSS re-examined. When the bill became over due, Mr. Alsford and I went into Turner's, the lawyers, in Whitechapel-road, and when we applied to them to proceed criminally against the prisoner and his sister, the clerk there said, "It is very much like old Mr. Layel's writing"—Turner was their attorney—he had some casein hand for the old gentle
man before.
MR. LAYEL re-examined. My daughter's expectations are beyond 100l.—she has never endeavoured to persuade me to give my name to my son, nor promised to make it good to me—she is nineteen years of age.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Had not your son applied

to you about advancing him a sum of money for the purpose of taking him abroad? A. He has been anxious to go abroad for some length of time and for me to get a sum of money to assist him in doing so, but it has not been in my power to do it—he has said that several times, in consequence of not getting any thing to do, he has asked me for money—I cannot say that it was for the specific object of taking him abroad—he mentioned several times that he should like to go abroad if he could get a steward's place, or something of that sort—he has very likely applied to me once or twice on that subject.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2503.
STEPHEN ALDHOUSE was indicted
for bigamy.
MESSRS. CLARKSON and BALLANTINE conducted the Prosecution.

GEORGE YARROW . I am parish clerk of St. Leonard, Shoreditch. I produce the original register of the marriages of that parish—on the 21st of January, 1824, I find a notice of the marriage of Mr. Aldhouse—(reads)—"Marriage solemnized in the parish of St. Leonard, Shoreditch. Stephen Aldhouse, of this parish, bachelor, and Frances Morse, alias Mon
tague, of St. Giles's, Norwich, spinster and minor, married by license, by consent of—. 21st January, by me, Robert Crosby, curate."—It is signed by Stephen Aldhouse and Mary Morse, in the presence of Chris
tian Appold, Mary Baker, and John George Appold. I have not got the license—it is generally rolled up and thrown away in some corner or other—it is not preserved.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. When people are married by license, the license is deposited in the chest, is it not? A. In some parishes they give it back to the parties, in our parish we generally detain them in the iron safe—I never looked there for this license—I do not know whether it is there or not—it is a thing that is never required.

JOHN GEORGE APPOLD . I live at No. 22, Wilson-street, Finsbury. I know the prisoner—I remember his being married in 1824, at Shoreditch church—I am one of the subscribing witnesses to the register—he and the lady he married went to the church to be married from my father's house—I had not known her previously—I think they remained at my father's house about a fortnight—the bride squinted—I do not know whether I am the only one of the subscribing witnesses alive—I do not know whether Mrs. Baker is alive or not.

GEORGE MORSE . I live at Cathurst, in Norfolk. I know Frances Morse, she is an illegitimate daughter of a half brother of mine, by a per
son named Montague—I saw her alive last about a month ago—I am one of her trustees—I have been in the habit of paying her her income since my brother's death, which was in April, 1833, down to this time, but not personally—she squints—this letter (looking at one) is in the writing of Mrs. Aldhouse, Frances Morse that was.

Cross-examined. Q. You say this lady's name is Montague? A. No, I never knew her by that name—I cannot tell that she is the daughter of a Miss Montague—she is known to me by the name of Morse—she is the illegitimate daughter of my brother, by a person named Montague—I can
not say How long it is since this marriage took place—I never saw this lady in company with the prisoner—I am unable to say whether she has been abroad—I do not know that she has been at Madeira——I pay her her money through Barclay's bank, I was living in one

place and she in another—it is derived from the funds—it is about 92l. half-yearly—she has been in the receipt of the property since my brother's death, or soon after—I never paid her anything before then—stamp receipts were given by my specific directions, at Barclay's bank
ing house, and transmitted to me at Messrs. Gurney's, of Norwich, who acted as my bankers—I was always directed to send her a notice, to a Mr. Hodges, in 'Change-alley, saying the money was lying in Barclay's bank on her application for it—she never came to me for it, except a month ago—I had not seen her from 1833 to 1842—I have never sought to find her otherwise than by letter, in short I never sought her at all, she has sought me, to ask for her dividend, and occasionally she applied to me for money in advance, which I have sometimes complied with—it is a month or five weeks since I saw her—it was ten or twelve years before that since—I had seen her, perhaps more—I have known her from her childhood—I have not seen her since her marriage in 1824, to my recollection—I have been applied to by the prisoner, by letter—I am unable to say when I was first written to by him—I had a letter from him in the year 1837, but that was not the first certainly—when the others came I cannot tell—I have had several letters from him, they are destroyed or taken no notice of—I neither answered them or took any care to keep them—they were destroy
ed, to the best of my belief—I cannot form a conception whether the first was five, or seven, or ten years ago—I had one in 1837, and one or two I daresay before—I had not one in 1833, at least I should say, if I had one in 1833 it must have been in the latter part of it, because my brother was alive in 1833, and I had nothing to do with the affair then—the prisoner, in his early letters to me, was constantly asking me to tell him where his wife was—I did not inform him—the question whether the was in ex
istence or not was never put—I never answered any of the letters except the last—he pursued the inquiry in the different letters to know where his wife was—to the best of my belief I never answered any of them—the last letter was in 1837—that letter is in existence, and I believe is in Court now, and also my answer to it—I never answered any of his letters but that, to the best of my belief—that last letter referred to an advertise
ment, which the prisoner had put into the paper, but I believe no others did—I will not swear it, but I believe it—to the best of my recollection the prisoner's former letters did not refer to an advertisement respecting Mrs. Aldhouse, offering a reward of 20l. to any person that would give information of her—I cannot recollect any thing about it, because I took no notice of the letters—I do not of my own knowledge know of any place Mrs. Aldhouse has lived in—she has never told me that she has been to Madeira—Morse was the only name she went by—I never knew her by any other name—she never adopted her mother's name—I never had any communication with any of the family till my brother died.

WILLIAM WEBB . I am parish clerk of St. James, Clerkenwell. I produce a register of the marriages of that parish—on the 4th of January, 1838, it appears a marriage was solemnized between the Rev. Stephen Aldhouse, widower, clerk, in holy orders, of No. 33, Red Lion-street, and Hephziba Roberts, widow, of Albion-terrace, Wandsworth-road.
Cross-examined. Q. Was this marriage by licence or banns? A. By license—I have not got it with me.
HEPHZIBA ROBERTS . I was married to the prisoner at St. James, Clerkenwell—I was at that time the widow of John Roberts, a publican—

the prisoner stated himself to be a widower—he said his former wife had died from excessive drinking, that she had drowned herself from excestivt drinking, and that he and her father identified her body—I have two chil
dren by him—I have been separated from him for two years and, I think seven months—at that time I had heard of his former wife being alive—I was not able to satisfy myself of the fact at the actual time of my leaving him—my mind was in doubt on the subject—I know a person of the name of Mrs. Pool—she has been represented to me as a sister of the prisoner—I once showed this letter to the prisoner, and asked him if he knew the handwriting—he said he did not, but he believed it to be that of Mrs. Aldhouse's sister, a lady of the name of Hill, who had got his eldest child—I do not know whether I asked him if it was his wife's handwriting.

Cross-examined. Q. When did your husband die? A. On the 17th of March, 1837—I was married in the January following—I was "in weeds" the whole of that time—the prisoner can give the best reason for my not waiting the year out—I had known him about seven months previous to our marriage—he was living at No. 33, Red Lion-street, Clerkenwell—he was not performing duty anywhere, to my knowledge—I heard him preach once during the period at Woolwich church—he introduced himself to me at my own house, in Lower Whitecross-street, City—at the time I mar
ried him I was residing with my father, at Albion-terrace, Wandsworth-road—I know the prisoner's family—I have seen his father, and his two brothers, and his sister, Mrs. Pool—I did not go on a visit to them pre
vious to my marriage—I saw them at my own house—I do not know whether he stated to them that I was his intended wife—I was received by them, and treated kindly—I cannot say whether Mr. Aldhouse ever represented me to them as his intended—nothing passed between the pri
soner's father and brothers and me as to his approaching marriage—I do not recollect that the subject was ever introduced by the father—none of the family attended the marriage—his father has visited me once since our separation, but not while we lived together—Mr. John Aldhouse visited me once during our stay at Gravesend—Mr. Aldhouse's father was a guard to a mail-coach—he resides at Norwich—I was down there three years ago this month, I think—I was received by his family very kindly—I went down to ascertain the fact whether the real Mrs. Aldhouse was alive, there
fore it can hardly be said that I went down as his wife—the prisoner's re
lations were not received at my father's at all—the prisoner's youngest brother visited me at my house in Whitecross-street—that was before the marriage—I never consulted him on the subject of the marriage—he was there frequently before the marriage—I cannot charge my memory How long before—I saw Sir William Forster when I went into the country, and received some information from him—I went down to Norwich with that intention—I told him what Mr. Aldhouse had told me, that his first wife had drowned herself—he said it was a falsehood, and if it was true some
body must be humbugging him, by receiving the money that was constantly paid to her—he said he had never seen Mrs. Aldhouse, he did not person
ally know her—I believe he is one of her trustees.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. How did the prisoner introduce himself to you? A. He called at my house in the first instance, and asked if I would allow a lady who accompanied him to sit down—he called the following day with a walking-stick, and asked my permission to leave it there, to which I con
sented—he called again and again, and it ended in this—my eldest child
by my former marriage is just six years old—my eldest by the prisoner if turned three, and the youngest, two.

COURT. Q. How long before you separated from him, had you a sus
picion that his former wife was still alive? A. My mind was in doubt on the subject from the month of September till March following—I went to see his sister, who had never been to see me since my marriage, and I had not been in her presence half-an-hour when she told me that his wife was living—I asked her what proof she had of the fact, and her reply was, at near as I can recollect, that her brother had no proof of her death—I im
mediately went home to my father, and stated the circumstance to him, and he said, in the event of my not being able to prove it, I was in duty bound to believe him innocent, but if I could prove it, there was a home for me to come to—that was one ground of our separation—there were other causes—this letter which has been produced was given to me by Sir William Foster.

ELIZABETH JOKES . I live at Egham, in Surrey. The prisoner lodged with me ten or eleven years ago—he came from Mr. Kingbam's, on Engle
field-green, and took my lodgings for a month—he did not tell me why he took them—he left me about the end of the month, suddenly, and said he should come back again—he left a deal box behind him—he afterwards returned—he then told me that he had gone away because a sheriff's officer had come from Kingston—he was sitting in the parlour at breakfast, and he said, if any one came, I was to say he was out, and he went down the passage into the garden—I told him on his return who it was that came in after him, and he said it was for some debts that his wife had contracted, and he would not meet them—he said nothing more about his wife—he did not speak of those debts as having been contracted some time before—he did not say any more than that—I told him it was very unpleasant having a person call like that—he said it was some debts that his wife had contracted, and he was not able to meet them.

RICHARD HENRY GEORGE . I am son-in-law of Mrs. Jones—in 1891 I was living at Egham—I saw the prisoner there and became acquainted with him—he told me he was resident at Egham for a short time, owing to some law proceedings that were pending at that time, brought on by the extravagance of his wife—he made some remarks respecting an elder child of his—he said if his wife was, I think he said, a more serene, a more quiet woman, he should be much more happy in his mind, but it is so long ago I almost forget the word—it is eleven years since—it was in June, I think.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose you did not make a memorandum of this interesting conversation? A. Certainly not—whether he said "se
rene," or any other expression, I would not swear—he said something about debt, and something about a wife.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Was it something about a wife living or dead? A. About a wife living, I should conceive, because he stated that his wife did not allow him to see his first child, or have his first child—of course I concluded that his wife was living.

MR. MORSE (re-examined by the COURT.) The purport of all the letters I received from the prisoner, as far as my recollection goes, was to know where his wife was—speaking of her as "my wife," and "what has become of her"—an annuity was paid to her after her separation, and has been up to this day—it would not have become his if she had died—it was
willed to her by my brother, to her sole and separate use during her life, and afterwards it goes to her children.

Q. Might not his inquiries have been to know whether there was anything to which he was entitled, under the impression that she was no longer receiv
ing it, that she was dead? A. It never appeared so to me—the last of those inquiries was in 1837—I cannot recollect when the first was—they might have come at various times—there were none as early as 18, 30—I never had anything to do with the property until my brother died, which was on the 6th of April, 1833—I have no objection to state my motive for keeping him ignorant of the place of her abode—I returned no answer ex
cept to the last letter—that was in 1837—I did not tell whether she was or where she was—I had every reason to believe, from various histories that I had heard, that his motive was not a good one—and as far as relates to his inquiries as to where his wife was, I was in total ignorance of her resi
dence—I could not have told anybody where she was—I could not tell myself—I tried to discover in various ways—I merely corresponded with her about her money, and my letters were always desired to be addressed to a Mr. Hodges, in Change-alley, Cornhill—that correspondence was with her—she wrote merely, "Address to me, at Mr. Hodges', No. 20 some
thing, Change-alley, Cornhill"—she studiously kept her residence con
cealed from me, as she has more than once stated to me, fearing I should tell her husband where she was—she was not living at Norwich to my knowledge—she was born there, and it was her home until she married—she was always called Morse—my brother did not educate her as a child—the mother lived in a separate house—he visited the mother constantly, and always brought her sister and two sons up in the same name—I was not at the christening of any of them—I never heard her called by the name of Montague, nor do I believe she ever was—I was not present at the marriage—she invariably bore the name of Morse—Sir William Foster is my co-trustee for the children, and co-executor—she never resided where Sir William Foster lived—he never saw her at all, I believe, at least, not to know her—he could not have given any information about her.

Q. So that all inquiries would have been baffled if the prisoner had made them most diligently, to find her out? A. As far as we were con
cerned, but in his letters to me he always asked me to tell him where his wife was—I understood from her, when I saw her a month ago, that they have been separated nearly thirteen years—since her separation I have always understood she has been attending to the education of her two daughters, and keeping them, as far as possible, concealed from the family, entirely eluding inquiry—she has the interest of a little more than 5, 000l. in the 31/2 per Cents.—I should suppose it was his interest in a pe
cuniary point of view to have lived with her, and that always appeared to me to be the motive for his letters—I have never seen her since her mar
riage until a month ago—I did not see her when she was married—I know her before she married—she has always gone by the name of Aldhouse since her marriage—I have directed letters to her, and she has written to me—the prisoner's inquiries were after that person as his wife—I was the half brother of her father.

COURT to R. H. GEORGE. Q. Your conversation with the prisoner was as far back as 1831—was there anything to draw your recollection to the precise language that passed? A. Why, he was stating that his partner in life was not a very comfortable one, he could not live with her—I under
stood

that he was involved in law proceedings—probably it was on account of a by-gone transaction of his wife's—my impression is, that he spoke of his wife as then living—he was not a stranger, I had met him several times on the same ground—my impression at the time was, that his wife was living—he stated it in that way—he did not positively say his wife was living—he said his wife would not allow him to see his child—that he particularly spoke of, and it was a child for whom he had some fondness apparently—he spoke of that precise time—that is my impression—I am confident it was in 1831, because I came to Egham in April, 1831—I was at Wands
worth before the Magistrate, but was not called.

Q. What led to this familiarity between you and the prisoner, that he should talk of his affairs to you? A. He frequently took the same walk that I took in the evening, and, from the number of times I saw him, we came into conversation with each other, and, from his dejected manner, I took the liberty of asking him the cause of his appearing so dejected—I am confident of the time, from letters which I have at home.

ELIZABETH JONES
re-examined. The prisoner left a deal box behind with me—about a year and a half ago, my son-in-law took the hinges off it—Mrs. Aldhouse came down, and I gave all the letters up to her—I do not know How the box came to be left behind—he had nothing more to take away—I did not know but that he was going to return—he only lodged with me a month, and I think it is about ten years ago—I am sure it was not in 1829—it was about May, I think—George was not my son-in-law at that time—he worked at Egham as a saddler.

GUILTY. Aged 40.—Recommended to mercy, having lost sight of his first wife for so many years, and no attention being paid to his in
quiries respecting her .—
Transported for Seven Years.

(The prosecutrix stated that the prisoner received 100l. from her father on her marriage; that the prisoner had represented to her that he was ap
pointed head master of a proprietary school at Gravesend, and unless married he should lose it; instead of which, he was merely endeavouring to establish a private one; and that she had submitted to a continued series of ill-usage from him.)

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant

div1.p:
2504.
SAMUEL CARTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of August, 61/2oz. weight of silk, value 3s., the property of
William Chaplin and another, his masters; to which he pleaded

GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy .—
Confined Six Months.

2505.
MARY WHITE was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of August, I purse, value 1d.; 3 sovereigns, and 7 half-eagles, value 7l., the pro
perty of
John White, from his person.
The prosecutor did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

2506.
MARY SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of August, 1 gown, 6s.; 1 shawl, value 6s.; and 1 apron, value 6d.; the goods of
Sarah Mary Carpenter.

SARAH MARY CARPENTER . I am single, and live in East-street, Mary
lebone—the prisoner came to lodge with me on the 7th of June. On the 31st of July, I went out, and returned on the 1st of August—I then missed my gown and shawl—these now produced are mine.
SARAH PAVEY . I live in Barretts-court—the prisoner brought this shawl to me on Sunday, the 31st of July, and asked if I would lend her 1s. 6d. on it, which I did.
WILLIAM JONES . I am a pawnbroker—the prisoner pawned this gown with me on the 1st of August.
Prisoner's Defence. I had very little work to do, and I intended to redeem the property again.

GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Confined Three Months.

2507.
JOHN JONES PHALOUR was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of July, 2 reams of paper, value 1l. 2s; and 2 account-books, value 9s.; the goods of
Henry Harrison and another.
The prosecutor did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

2508.
WILLIAM SADD,
GEORGE HENRY LYNE , and
JAMES WRIGHT, alias James Fenables
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July, 1 half-crown, and 2 half-pence, the monies of
Charles Realff, from the person of
Charlotte Realff; and that Sadd and Lyne had been before convicted of felony.

CHARLOTTE REALFF . I am the wife of Charles Realff, a coach-painter, of Charlotte-street, Whitechapel. About three o'clock in the afternoon on the 27th of July, I was walking along Greenfield-street, and heard a cry of "Stop thief!"—I put my hand in my pocket, and found I had lost a half-crown and two halfpence.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How lately before had you felt your money? A. About ten minutes—I was then in Fieldgate-street.

WILLIAM BRADLEY . I live at Seal, in Leicestershire. I was in Field-gate-street that afternoon—I felt the prisoners at my pocket—in conse
quence of that I watched and saw Sadd and Lyne go to the prosecutrix—Sadd put his hand into her pocket—Wright was on the other side of the way—when I saw Sadd put his hand into the prosecutrix's pocket, I crossed over and seized him—Wright then crossed the road and seized his hand, and tried to get some money from him—I seized Sadd and Wright—Sadd dropped a half-crown and two halfpence.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you living in town? A. I arrived the day before—Mrs. Harrison was with me—I saw the prisoners for about ten minutes before the prosecutrix was robbed—I am quite sure I am not mistaken as to Wright being one of the persons I had seen before—Mrs. Harrison was not examined at Lambeth-street—to the best of my know
ledge she had the same opportunity of seeing this as I had—she was a little before me—we were going to her husband.
Lyne. Q. Are you quite sure you saw me behind Sadd when it was done? A. Yes, and you shielded him with your coat.

Sadd's Defence. I have no wish to criminate others, but, had it not been for persons working on my youth, and holding out temptations which I had not the sense to withstand, I should not be placed at this bar; I beg for mercy.

Lynes Defence. I know nothing of either of these boys; I have not been long from sea; I belong to a ship called the Recovery, belonging to Mr. Gibson; I have been to America. and been several voyages in the. coal trade.
JOHN SHEER (police-constable H 184.) I produce a certificate of Sadd's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(ready)—he is the person.
BENJAMIN PHILLIPS (police-consiable G 58.) I produce a certificate of Lyne's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—he is the person.

SADD—
GUILTY . Aged 14.

LYNE—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

WRIGHT—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

2509.
JOHN HUGHES was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of July, 6 knives, value 1l.; 6 forks, value 1l.; and 1 spoon, value 1l.; the goods of
William Henderson.

HENRY KNAPP . I am groom to Colonel William Henderson, of Ham
mersmith. On the 29th of July, I placed these knives and other things en the table in the dining-room—I missed them in about twenty minutes—these now produced are them—they are my master's.

GEORGE CHAMBERLAIN . I am a bricklayer, and live in Wells-lane, Hammersmith. On the 29th of July, I saw the prisoner, and three com
panions, near the water side—one of them went to Colonel Henderson's, and got in at the window—the prisoner and the other two were outside watching—when the prisoner saw the policeman he whistled—I gave in
formation, and he was brought back in a few minutes—the prisoner or one of his companions threw these things down, and I took them up.
JAMES HAMON (police-constable T 149.) I took the prisoner, and received the property from Colonel Henderson's servant.
MART ANN WEARING . I received this plate from Mr. Chamberlain, and gave it to my fellow servant.

Prisoner's Defence. I was walking along the shore, and there were three young lads—one of them got in at the window, I believe, but I did not see it—I heard a cry of "Stop thief"—I ran to stop them, and two men stopped me.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

2510.
BENJAMIN PEDIGREE was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of August, 1 pair of boots, value 4s., the goods of
Charles Wright, from the person of
James Wright; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

JAMES WRIGHT . I live with my father Charles Wright, in Essex-street, Hackney. On the 13th of August, I was playing in Bishop Bon
ner's field—the prisoner came to me, laid me on my back on a bank, and took my boots off.
ALFRED COPE . I am nine years old. I was playing in the field—I saw the prisoner running down the bank with a pair of boots in his hand—I am sure he is the person.
JAMES FREDERICK TROVELL . I am a pawnbroker. I have the boots—they were pawned with me by a boy, on the 14th—I cannot say who it was.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
THOMAS COOK (police-constable K 174.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2511.
WILLIAM DEAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of August, 1 half-crown, 9 shillings, 5 sixpences, and 3 groats, the monies of
Robert Mayes, and that he had been before convicted of felony.

ROBERT MAYES . I was coming up by the Great Western Railway, and met with the prisoner—we had a long talk together, and at last we went to a public-house, where we were to sleep—the prisoner said he had only 4d.—I had nine shillings, one half-crown, five sixpences, and three groats—when I went to bed I doubled my trowsers up, and put them under my head—the money was in them then—the prisoner was there, but he was not undressed—when I awoke in the morning he was gone, and my money also—I got a policeman, and we found him at the Red Lion, Edgeware-road—there was 8s. found on him.

Prisoner. You said, "If you can find me a lodging, I will stand treat"—I said, "I do not wish that, I have money in my pocket"—we had two half-pints of gin—I paid for one, and you for the other. Witness. I asked you if you could inform me of a lodging, and you said, "Yes, a comfortable good lodging"—you took me to the house, and said you had only 4d.—I treated you with a bit of supper, and gave you twopence to get a pint of beer in the morning.

SARAH POCOCK . The prosecutor and prisoner came to my home to sleep—when the prisoner took the 2d. of the other man, he said he had no money—the prisoner went up stairs, but did not go to bed—he laid down on the bed with his clothes on, and in about half-an-hour he wanted to go out.

Prisoner's Defence. This man asked me if I could get him a lodging; we both went and drank, and after I had stopped some time, I went to go to bed; I had 12s. when I started from home, which I had worked for; we were both tipsy; I do not know what I did.

OTHO HENRY STEED (police-constable D 182.) I produce a certi
ficate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2512.
JOHN BURNS and
JAMES SMITH were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 18th of August, 1 pair of boots, value 3s. 6d.; and 1 pair of socks, value 6d.; the goods of
Edward Stokoe.

EDWARD STOKOE . I live in Westbourn-street, Pimlico. On the 18th of August, I was in a field, and took off my boots and socks to go into the Thames—the prisoners were there—I saw Burns take my boots and give them to Smith—they ran away together.
WILLIAM EVANS . I saw Burns take the boots up from the and give them to Smith—they ran away together.
Burns's Defence. We were running after two other boys; we nothing about the boots; there were a lot more boys bathing.

BURNS—
GUILTY . Aged 12.

SMITH—
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Four Months.

2513.
JOHN HUBBARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of August, 90lbs. weight of stone, value 1s., the goods of
Thomas Cubitt.

JAMES JEFFREY . I live at Hendon-wharf, Pimlico, and am in the employ of Mr. Thomas Cubitt. About half-past eight o'clock in the morning of the 20th of August, I went into a vault where there was a great quantity of stones belonging to Mr. Cubitt—I saw the prisoner watching about—he went into the vault and took out this lump of hearth stone—he had it under his arm, and when he saw me he dropped it, and ran off.
Prisoner's Defence. I went down; there was a lot of rubbish; I was kicking it over, and this man called, "Stop thief;" I was taken, and this stone was brought; I had not touched it.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

2514.
CHARLES CROCKILL was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of August, 2 razors, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Clater.
THOMAS CLATER . I live at Chelsea; the prisoner was in the habit of coming to my shop. On the 10th of August I lost two razors in a red case—they had ivory handles, and the name "T. Clater" on them.

JOHN WILD . I am a hair-dresser, and live in George-street, Chelsea. The prisoner brought two razors to me for sale—they had white handles, and "T. Clater" on them—he said he saw a gentleman drop them out of his pocket, and he took them up—I did not buy them—they have not been found.
NOT GUILTY .

2515.
AMELIA CATES was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of August, 91/2 yards of mouselin de laine, value 14s., the goods of
Samuel Hughes and another.

SAMUEL HUGHES . I am in partnership with James Dean; we are linen
drapers, and live in White chapel-road; the prisoner was in the habit of coming to our shop. On the 18th of August I counted some pieces of mouselin de laine, and placed them on the counter, as I rather expected the prisoner would come—she came in about a quarter of an hour, and bought half a yard of calico—I then missed some mouselin de laine—I followed and brought her back—she dropped this piece on the floor, in the middle of the shop, from tinder her shawl.
Prisoner. I did not have it at all. Witness. You had got out of the shop, two doors off—I brought you back myself, and saw you drop it.

Prisoner's Defence. I said I had nothing; he opened my shawl, and there was nothing there; he said he had missed a gown-piece; it was be
hind the counter, and he said I took it.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

2516.
MARIA SINCLAIR and
ANN SMITH were indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of July, 9 sovereigns, 7 half-crowns, and 3 shil
lings, the monies of
Hammond Sears, from his person; and that Sinclair had been before convicted of felony.
The prosecutor did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

2517.
ELLEN DAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of July, 1 jacket, value 10s., the goods of
David Ballard. The prosecutor did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

2518.
MARGARET RAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of August, 1 shawl, value 4s.; 1 frock, value 2s.; 2 gowns, value 7s.; 2 sheets, value 2s.; 1 petticoat, value 1s.; 1 apron, value 6d.; 1 handker
chief, value 1s.; 1 bed-tick, value 2s. 6d.; and 1 quilt, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Catherine Hillman.

CATHERINE HILIMAN . I am a widow, and live in Bluegate-fields. On the 10th of August I went to Hampton Court, leaving the prisoner, who was my servant, in care of my house—when I returned my house was stripped of the articles stated—they are here, and are mine.

Prisoner. The petticoat she gave me; her daughter knows she gave it me; the handkerchief is not hers; she keeps a house of the worst descrip
tion; she has brought men home to me; I told her I was going to see my little boy, in the City; she said I might pledge this gown and shawl of hers. Witness. I did not give her the petticoat or anything.
HENRY KINGSFORD . I am shopman to a pawnbroker. I produce some articles pawned by a young woman, I cannot say who.
PAUL MALONY . I am a pawnbroker. I produce some articles—I took in this bed-tick and sheet from the prisoner.
Prisoner. She told me if there was anything I could make money of, I was to pawn it; she has been convicted herself three times; last Easter Tuesday twelvemonth she had six months for a watch.

CATHERINE HILLMAN
re-examined. Never—I did not authorise her to take anything—she took my shawl from the mangler's.
NOT GUILTY .

2519.
WILLIAM JOHN SHAW was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of August, 1 pair of trousers, value 1s. 6d.; 1 shirt, value 1s; 1 cap, value 6d.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 2s.; and 7 shillings; the pro
perty of
Frederick Cooper; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

FREDERICK COOPER . I live in Steven-street, Bethnal-green-road. I went to bathe on the 18th of August, and left my trousers and money on the shore—when I came out all my things were gone—when I went into the water the prisoner was lying on a bar, which parted the field from the little path—a boy detected him, and took my clothes from him as I war running up the side of the canal naked—these are my clothes—I lost seven shillings, and 6s. 101/2d. was found on him—this handkerchief, which if mine, was returned with the clothes—they were taken by a boy not here.
WILLIAM CATLIN . I heard a cry of "Stop thief"—I saw the prisoner running—I ran after him—I saw him drop this handkerchief—I picked it up, and gave it to the officer.
WILLIAM FRENCH (police-constable N 151.) I took the prisoner—I found 101/2d. in his right hand.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) I went in pursuit of the pri
soner—we caught him at Cambridge Heath-bridge—I laid hold of one hand, and my brother officer the other—in the lining of the waist of his trowsers I found six shillings—as we were going to search him, he said, "You have no occasion to search me, I will give it up," and he did.

WILLIAM EDWARD BALL (police-constable N 365.) I produce a cer
tificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Transported for Seven Years.—Convict Ship.

2520.
GEORGE RICHARDS was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of August, 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Henry Hull, from hit person.

HENRY HALL . I live in Astey's-row, Lower-road, Islington. At a quarter past seven o'clock, on the 18th of August, I was at a large meeting on Islington-green—Ball spoke to me, and I missed my handkerchief from my coat-pocket—this is it.

EDWARD BALL (police-constable N 65.) On the 18th of August there was a Chartist meeting on Islington-green—I watched the prisoner some time—I saw him take this handkerchief from the prosecutor's coat-pocket—I took him with it.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined One Month.

2521.
JANE WILSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of August, 3 half-crowns, 1 shilling, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
Henry Lewis, from his person; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

HENRY LEWIS . I am a cab-driver, living in Cobham-row. I met the prisoner in Gray's-inn-lane on the 26th of August—I gave her 1s., and went to a room with her—I had three half-crowns, one shil
ling, and one sixpence—I missed it, and told the prisoner so—she said she had not got it, she knew nothing about it—I then had a scuffle with her, and saw her throw one half-crown, one shilling, and a sixpence on the bed—I asked her to give me the others—she would not—I sent for a police
man—when he came to the top of the stairs, she gave me the other two half-crowns.
SAMUEL DOTLE (police-constable G 197.) I took the prisoner—the prosecutor said she gave him this money—I saw her give him something—I do not know what it was.

Prisoner's Defence. He said, "If you do not give me half-a-crown of your own money, I will serve you out," and he struck me shamefully; I said I could not; he went down, and got a policeman; he had not given me any thing; he said he was in the habit of serving every girl so that he went with: I found two half-crowns under the foot of the bed; I do not know whether they were his or not; I never saw anything of the half
crown, the shilling, and the sixpence.
SAMUEL DOYLE (police-constable G 197.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—she is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2522.
JOHN WILLIAMS and
BRIDGET BURKE were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of August, 1 shawl, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas Smith.

CHARLES REEVE . I am assistant to Thomas Smith, a pawnbroker, in Pitfield-street, Hoxton. On the 26th of August I was in the shop—Burke came, and unpinned this shawl which was outside the door—she went across the road, and spoke to Williams, who came across, and stood at the door—Burke then came in, and inquired the price of the shawl, and as she went out took the shawl with her—Williams and she walked off together—I went, and took it from her—this is it.
Williams. I saw many persons rush out of the shop, seize Burke, and
this man came, and said, "You are accessory to stealing this shawl." Witness. She unpinned the shawl, then went and spoke to him—he came, and stood at the door—he came across the road with her.
Burke's Defence. I saw the shawl lay on the ground; I took it up, and gave it to him.

WILLIAMS—
NOT GUILTY .

BURKE—
GUILTY . Aged 50.—
Confined Three Months.

2523.
MARY SMITH was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
George Marshall, on the 28th of July, putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 bag, value 2d.; 6 sovereigns, 1 half-sovereign, 1 shilling, 1 groat, 2 5l. notes, his property, and using personal violence to him.
The prosecutor did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

2524.
EDWARD GIFFORD and
SARAH ANN HUNT were in
dicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 6th of January, 124 yards of silk, value 11l.; 12 yards of merino, value 12s.; 33 yards of ribbon, value 10s.; and 120 boot-laces, value 2s.; the goods of
John Palk Griffin, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.
MR. LUCAS conducted the Prosecution.

CHARLES JAMES COVERLY GRIFFIN . I am the son of John Palk Griffin. On the 5th or 6th of January last, when I left ray father's pre
mises in Ironmonger-lane, Cheapside, I locked the door, and left it secure—I came the next morning, and found the premises had been broken open, the policeman there, the property in confusion, and property to the amount of 600l. or 700l. taken away—amongst it were two pieces of silk, twelve yards of merino, thirty-three yards of ribbon, and 120 boot-laces—a por
tion of each are here now, and I can swear to them as ours.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How do you know them? A. I know this silk by our mark being on it in my own writing—I know it had not been sold, because it was in the warehouse on the night of the robbery.

JOHN GRAY (police-sergeant C 14.) On the 4th of July, from infor
mation, I went to No. 5, Warwick-street, Charing-cross, and found Hunt there—I asked her if Mr. Gifford was at home—she said he was not, Mr. and Mrs. Gifford were gone to Gravesend—I said I had a warrant to search the house, and produced it—I asked her if she had any keys of the upper part of the house—she said she had not, Mr. and Mrs. Gifford had taken them with them to Gravesend—I then went up stairs—shortly after I let Gifford in—he had a brown paper parcel, which I opened—it contained these two pieces of silk—I afterwards found some keys lying on the side
board in the front parlour—I said, "What keys are these?"—one of them opened a cupboard in the front parlour, where I found some ribbon, and the other the attic, where I found an immense mass of property—these are the boot-laces and the ribbon—I found some of them in the attic, and some in the front parlour, and in a writing-desk in the back parlour I found a gold chain, two brooches, two diamond rings, a watch-hook, a seal, a pearl ring, a diamond pin, and in the front parlour I found ten eye-glasses, a locket, a brooch, and a pair of earrings—this blood-stone ring I found on Handley's person (see p. 907)—there were some other
things found on Gilford's person, by my brother officer—Hunt said she lived with Mr. Gifford, as housekeeper.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was it when you went in that you asked where Mr. Gifford was? A. Yes, I knew ha was living in that house.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you make these searches in Gifford's absence? A. Yes, we were searching about an hour.

COURT. Q. Did you say any thing to either of them about the pro
perty? A. I said to Gifford, "Here is a large quantity of property in your possession, you must give some account of it"—he said he would not then, but would to-morrow before the Magistrate.
JOHN WHALL (police-sergeant C 16.) I found on Gifford's person four pins, and a pearl brooch in his pocket-book, and five diamonds, and two opals in his pocket, a pencil-case, and a gold chain.

FULGENCE PIGARCHE . I am partner in the house of Veco, lace manu
facturers, at Paris. In June, 1841, I was living at Wright's hotel, in London—I had a quantity of lace with me—in the beginning of June I had occasion to send a box of lace and other things, worth about 150l., to the West-end—I employed a porter to carry it—I went there, and found neither the porter or the lace had arrived—amongst the contents of the box was this lace shawl, and these other things—the amount of the property here is 40l. or 50l.—the shawl is spoiled.

HENRY LAMBERT . In October last I was a jeweller, living in Cheap
side. On Sunday, the 3rd of October, my premises were entered, and nearly the whole of my property, from 700l. to 900l. worth taken away—four or five of these articles I can positively swear to as mine—they are worth about 25l. or 30l., and some other as I believe to be mine from having similar.

GIFFORD—
GUILTY . Aged 33.

HUNT—
NOT GUILTY .

2525.
EDWARD GIFFORD and
SARAH ANN HUNT were again indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 28th of February, 8 lace shawls, value 13l.; 26 lappets, value 8l.; 19 berthes, value 8l.; 81 capes, value 21l.; 83 cambric caps, value 35l.; 11 lace dresses, value 29l.; 27 falls, Value 10l.; 28 veils, value 19l.; 12 collars, value 4l.; 38 scarfs, value 30l.; and 10 muslin collars, value 4l.; the goods of
Samuel Lambert; well knowing them to have been stolen; against the statute, &c.; to which

GIFFORD pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.
MR. CHAMBERS conducted the Prosecution.

FREDERICK HERBERT HEMMING . I am agent to Samuel Lambert, a lace-manufacturer—he has a place of business in Aldermanbury. In Feb
ruary last I packed up a quantity of lace to go to the country—I delivered it to Beale, a porter, to take to the Swan-with-Two-Necks—I can swear to a great part of these things found, as being part of them.
RICHARD BEALE . I am a porter. I took this box of lace to the Swan-with-Two-Necks—while I was engaged in putting up a carpet-bag, the box of lace was stolen.
JOHN WHALL (police-sergeant C 16.) I went to Warwiek-street with Gray on the 4th of July—I knocked at the door—it was opened by the servant—I saw Hunt in the parlour, lying on the sofa—Gray asked her

whether Mr. or Mrs. Gifford were at home—she said they were at Graves. end—we told her we had a search-warrant to search the house for certain stolen property—we asked her if she had any keys, as we should com
mence at the top of the house—she said Mr. and Mrs. Gifford had takes the keys with them to Gravesend—we went up stairs, and began searching the top of the house—in the back attic we found a great quantity of ske
leton-keys, life-preservers, jemmies, and other things—Gray went down stairs—he came up again in two or three minutes, and then we broke open the door of the front attic—we found the room full of silks and other things, some in a cupboard, and some on the floor, in a confused state—we then came down into the parlour—Hunt was still there—in a short time a knock came to the door, which was opened by Gray, and Gifford came in—Gray asked him if he was not Mr. Gifford—he said "Yes"—he said, "Are you master of this house?"—he said, "I am"—we then went into the parlour—Hunt said she was housekeeper to Mr. Gifford—we told Gifford the nature of our business, and showed him the warrant—we then searched the front parlour, where Gray found some property—I went into the back parlour, and found there a basket, with dirty linen at the top. and clean linen at the bottom, and in the middle was a quantity of lace wrapped up in this brown paper—some of the linen belonged to a man. and some to a woman—I know where Gifford lived before—Hunt passed as his wife—I have seen her living in the same house.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you not find these skeleton-keys in a room which you understood was occupied by a man named Handley? A. I have heard so—I have been in the house, but I never spoke to Hunt before—a Mrs. Hancock was indicted for keeping the house.

JOHN GRAY (police-sergeant C 14.) I assisted in searching the house—I found the door of the front attic locked—I went down, and asked Hunt if she had the keys of the front attic—she said she had not—we broke it open—on coming down again I saw some keys on the sideboard in the front parlour—I said, "What are these?"—she said, "One will open the front attic"—I said, "It is too late now"—she said, "I thought Mr. and Mrs. Gifford had taken them with them to Gravesend"—I found two pieces of lace in the front parlour cupboard.

MARY WATKINS . I lived as servant, in Eyre-street, for three months up to the 1st of June, with Mrs. Hunt, who used to pass as Mrs. Good,—Gifford used to pass as Mr. Good—on some occasions Handley has come there—sometimes both Mr. and Mrs. Good were at home—some
times Handley has brought a parcel in his hand, sometimes not, and if Mr. and Mrs. Good were engaged, he was shown into the drawing-room till they were at liberty—if not, they used to go into the back parlour, and no one was admitted while they were there—when Mr. Good was not there, Handley saw Mrs. Good—I did not go with them when they removed to Warwick-street—it was an open house they kept in Eyre-street.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you examined at any of the ten examinations? A. No—Sergeant Gray came up to me in the street, and asked if my name was Mary Watkins—I said it was—he asked if I did not live in Eyre-street—I said I did—I gave him my address, No. 3, Red Lion-street, Seven-dials, where I am living with Mrs. Smith, a dress-maker—I lived in the house in Eyre-street three months—I knew it was a brothel when I went there—I had never lived at one before—I was told I had nothing to do but to wait on the master and mistress—the

other servant, Mary Kent, opened the door—I have not been at any other house in Eyre-street—I partook of some brandy and water with Sergeant Gray, at Mr. Robinson's, who keeps a public-house at the corner of Eyre-street—it is more than a week ago—I did not think there was any harm in it—he paid for it—he was in his uniform—he asked me a few questions about this case.

MARY JACKSON . In January last Mrs. Hunt employed me to take care of No. 5, Warwick-street—she then went by the name of Mrs. Gifford—I was to take care of the apartments, and to clean them—I remained there till June—I knew Mrs. Hunt lived in Eyre-street, and she told me the house was going to be indicted—she left it in the early part of June, and came to Warwick-street—she came on a Thursday or Friday morning, and I think the first week after she came, there were two cabs and a hackney-coach full of bundles came to the house—I do not know what they con
tained—they were put first into the parlour and the passage, and after
wards taken to the first-floor and the front attic—the front attic was always open till a few days before I came away, when a lock was put on it by Mrs. Hunt's order—Mr. Gifford came there about a week after Mrs. Hunt came—he used to pass as her husband—there is a back parlour if the house—it was used as a bed-room—Mrs. Hunt slept there—she kept the keys of the cupboards, and always paid me my wages—I used to let the house in lodgings—I always received the rent, and paid it to Mrs. Hunt.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Very respectable people lived there? A. Yes—a member of Parliament had the second-floor back room—Mr. Handley had the second-floor, and then removed to the back attic—I do not know whether Mr. Gifford or Mrs. Hunt knew him—he ap
peared a stranger.

JAMES BLOOMFIELD NORTON . I am clerk in the Phoenix Fire Office. I recollect Mrs. Hunt coming there, on the 6th of April last, to effect an insurance on furniture at No. 5, Warwick-street, Cockspur-street, Cha
ring-cross—she represented it as her own, and gave her name Sarah Ann Hunt.

CHARLOTTE HANDCOCK . I Live in Buckingham-street, Strand. I lived with the prisoners in Eyre-street—they went by the name of Mr. and Mrs. Good—Mr. Good was master of the house—I have seen Mrs. Hunt wear this black lace dress which is here produced—I believe the first time she wore it was at Ascot-races, fifteen months ago—I saw her with this shawl when she came from Boulogne—she told me Mr. Good gave it her.

FULGENCE PIGACHE
re-examined. This shawl is one that was in our parcel—the cost price of it was fourteen guineas.

FREDERICK HERBERT HEMMING
re-examined. This lace of ours I have examined—it is worth about 80l., and is in pieces, such as we should sell to the retail dealers.

HUNT.—
GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

2526.
BENJAMIN HANDLEY was indicted
for stealing on the 29th of June, at
St. James', Westminster, in the dwelling-house of
Elizabeth Huntley, 1 necklace, value 15l.; 1 ring, value 6l.; 1 neckchain, value 10l.; 1 vinaigrette, value 7l.; 2 boxes, value 2s. 6d.; 2 printed books, value 4l.; 5 brooches, value 10l.; and 3 pairs of earrings, value 8l.; the goods of
Elizabeth Bridget Rashdall: and 4 ladles, value 2l. 8s.;40 spoons, value 16l.; 36 forks, value 16l.; 1 pair of sugar-tongs, value 10s.; 2 sugar-sifters, value 1l. 10s.; 12 knives, value 2l.; and 1 padlock, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of
Lucy Rashdall: and
EDWARD GIFFORD and
SARAH ANN HUNT , for felonionsly receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; to which

HANDLEY
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 31.—
Judgment Respited.
MR. CHAMBERS offered no evidence against Gifford and Hunt.
NOT GUILTY .

2527.
THOMAS DAWKINS was indicted
for a misdemeanor; to which he pleaded
Fifth Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

2528.
MARY ANN DAVIS and
ESTHER HOWELL were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of August, 9 yards of lace, value 2l. 9s., the goods of
Thomas Stroud and others.

THOMAS STROUD . I am in partnership with John Howell and others, lacemen, in Regent-street. On the 2nd of August, the prisoners came to the shop together—they asked to look at some Valenciennes lace for collars, which I showed them, and they bought some, which came to 17s. 6d.—they appeared to be both together—they did not pay the whole of the money—they left the lace, and went out of the shop—I had shown them a great many pieces that they did not buy, and I showed them a piece of the pattern that is here produced—it is a new pattern.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did they leave any money? A. Yes, I think 16s.—I cannot say for a certainty—it might be 17s.—it was in silver—they had bargained for lace—both of them spoke—I am not positive which paid me.

GEORGE BURTON . I am the prosecutor's assistant—I remember the prisoners being there on the afternoon of the 2nd of August—Mr. Stroud was showing them lace—I watched them, and when they rose from their seats to leave the shop, the prisoner Howell dropped two pieces of lace about a yard from the counter—I followed them out of the shop, and con
tinued to keep them in sight till I was induced to give them in charge—I could not see what they were engaged in, but it appeared to me they were looking at some articles, or distributing something—they were talking—they did not see me till I put my hand on the shoulder of one of them—they were taken to Bow-street, and a piece of lace was there shown to me by Taylor—this is it—I know it to be the prosecutor's property from its general character, and from the pattern, which is peculiar—the lace that was dropped in the shop was taken up and put into the stock.

WILLIAM TAYLOR . I live in Cannon-square, Chelsea. I was walking in New-street, Covent-garden, on the evening of the 2nd of August—I met the two prisoners in custody—I followed them, and in Bow-street I picked up this piece of lace about a yard from the prisoner Howell—I gave it to the policeman.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What are you? A. I am out of business—I was attracted by seeing the prisoners go along—I was going into the city on business—I followed them, and was close behind them—I
saw Mr. Burton with them—he was moving his hand, and making signs to the policeman—when I picked this up, Burton was by the sick of one of the prisoners, and the policeman on a-head with the other.
(Frederick Shaw, a goldbeater; William Shaw, an accountant; George Sinclair, a rent-collector; and Mary Harding, wife of a painter and glazier, gave Howell a good character.)
(Davis received a good character.)

DAVIS—
GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined Twelve Months.

HOWELL—
GUILTY . Aged 27.—

2529.
ESTHER HOWELL was again indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of July, at
St. Marylebone, 27 yards of lace, value 10l., the goods of
William Turner Hayward, in his dwelling-house.
MR. ESPINASSE conducted the Prosecution.

FREDERICK SAUNDERS . I am assistant to William Turner Hayward—he is a lace dealer, and lives at No. 81, Oxford-street—it is his dwelling-house, and is in the parish of St. Mary-le-bone—the prisoner was in the habit of coming to my master's shop for lace, for the last nine or twelve months—it was customary to put the box of lace before her when she came—she came on the 13th of July—in consequence of suspicion I had counted twenty-two pieces of lace, and put them in the box—she took her seat at the counter—there were only these twenty-two pieces in the box, which was put before her, but there were three pieces of lace of a different description, about a yard from this—while she was looking at the lace I went into the warehouse, and brought back another piece of lace to her—she had then decided on one of the pieces in the box, and said, she intended to take a part of that which she had in her hand—I examined the pieces of lace in the box as well as I could, and found there were only nineteen—I called to Biddle who was in the shop—I afterwards saw four pieces of lace on the floor, close by where the prisoner had been sit
ting—I am perfectly able to say that they were in the box—they are worth about 10l. 16s., or 10l. cost price.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You took her before the Magi
strate on the 13th of July, and she was discharged, was not she? A. Yes—when she was in custody on the other charge I came again, and brought another witness—we did not know before that Mr. Biddle's evi
dence would be wanted—we had tried to find the prisoner, but could not—she said she lived in Denmark-street, but they denied her there—we taken went to Vincent-terrace, Islington, but could not find her—she may have had credit for 5s. or 6s. at our house.
COURT. Q. When you looked, you say there were nineteen pieces, How many had there been at first? A. Twenty-two, and I put one more, which made twenty-three.

DANIEL BIDDLE . I am shopman to Mr. Hayward. On the 13th of July I saw the prisoner at the shop—my attention was called to her by Mr. Saunders—I went over and stood by her side—Mr. Saunders accused her of having stolen some lace—she replied, "I am an honest woman; you know me very well; I have visited this shop some time as a customer"—I felt something fall down—I looked at my feet, and saw these four pieces of lace.

COURT. Q. How near was the prisoner at the time? A. She was sit
ting
on a chair, with her hand placed on the counter, and I was stand by her elbow.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you kept these pieces ever since, distinct from others? A. Yes; I put then in a piece of paper into a drawer, and locked them up.

PRISCILLA COOPER . I am assistant in Mr. Hayward's shop. I saw the prisoner in his shop on the 13th of July—Mr. Biddle was by her side—Mr. Saunders accused her of taking four pieces of lace, and I saw four pieces drop from under her shawl—Mr. Saunders was on the other side of the counter—I was behind the other counter, on the other side of the shop, about three yards from her.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2530.
STEPHEN ROBINSON was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

THOMAS HALFHIDE . I live in Thames-street; the prisoner is my nephew; he has professed of late to deal in horses. On the 31st of May he came to me about some horses, and I gave him some money to buy a hone for my son-in-law—he came on the 4th of June, and said he had bought a horse, and he had left 3l. 10s. as deposit for it, that the difference was 3l. 10s., and he wanted 3l. 10s. more to make up the price for it—in con
sequence of that I let him have three sovereigns and one half-sovereign—he gave it to a person whom he brought with him to receive the difference, because the proprietor would not let the horse go without it.
Prisoner. He lent me the money; I was to pay it back, and pay him interest. Witness. No.

HENRY SUMNER . I am the prosecutor's son-in-law. The horse was to be bought for me, but it never came to me—I went to the prisoner's house, and saw him, after waiting half an hour, at the Ship public-house—he came to me there—I told him I came for the horse—he said the horse did not turn out to his expectation, and he had given him a ball and turned bio out to grass; if I would meet him at seven o'clock the next morning, at Whitechapel, he would bring me a horse—I went five minutes before seven, and waited till half-past eight—I never saw him, nor the horse—he had promised to meet me to go to Rom ford to buy a horse.
WILLIAM NICOL (police-constable K 177.) I took the prisoner—I told him it was for getting 3l. 10s. of Mr. Half hide under false pretences—he said he gave it him to do as he liked with.

THOMAS HALFHIDE
re-examined. When he came to me he brought a person with him, and said he had paid a deposit for a horse which came to 7l., and he wanted 3l. 10s. more before he could have it.
Prisoner. I was to pay him interest; I could not make it up so soon as I could wish for.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 35.—Recommended to mercy .—
Confined One Month.

2531.
JAMES SAUNDERS was indicted
for unlawfully breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Cornelius Kelly on the 21st of July, at
Whitechapel, with intent to steal.
ELIZABETH KELLY . I am the wife of Cornelius Kelly—he has one room at No. 4, Plough-street, Whitechapel—it is his dwelling-house? and

is in the parish of Whitechapel—on the 21st of July, I went out at ten minutes or a quarter before four o'clock—I locked my room door and took my key—there are other persons have rooms in the house, and there is one common door to the house—I was out about ten minutes—when I returned I found my room door ajar—I pushed it open, and the prisoner was behind it—he put the door a little close, and ran to get between me and the door—I hallooed out—he ran out, and I followed him into the street—I took hold of him, and dragged him along—he got from me, and ran towards Back Church-lane—I followed, and called out—I never lost sight of him—he was caught, and I gave him to the officer—I saw some keys in the gutter—I took them up and gave them to the officer—I had desired Burrell to go and take care of my room—I had a box under the bed in my room—I am well aware it was locked when I went out—I have not missed anything—the prisoner had no business in my room—I never saw him before.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not lose sight of me? A. No, never—when I came back the box was unlocked—you broke it open with a chisel.

ELLEN BARRETT . The prosecutrix is my niece—I live next door to her—I was looking out at my window on the 21st of July, and saw her go out—I did not see her come back, but I heard her scream—I went down stairs, and she told me to take care of her house—I went and found one of her boxes drawn half-way from under the bed—it was unlocked.

WILLIAM SOUTHWICK . I am a boiler-maker, and live in the next room to the prosecutrix—I heard her cry, "Stop thief" on the 21st of July, and saw the prisoner running down Colchester-street—I laid hold of him, and kept him till the officer came.
JAMES SIMEON . I am a boiler-maker. I was with Southwick when he took the prisoner—I saw the prisoner throw three keys into the gutter and put his foot on them—the prosecutrix picked them up.

JOHN COX . I am a policeman. I was fetched to Colchester-street about a quarter before four o'clock that evening—I saw the prosecutrix, the pri
soner, and several persons round him—the prosecutrix charged him with being in her house, but she did not know whether he had taken anything—somebody called out about the prisoner's left hand pocket—I searched it, and found in it two keys and a chisel, and in his other pocket this empty bag—I have these other keys, which were given me by the prose
cutrix—the prisoner tried to get away, and the mob was against his being taken to the station—I tried those keys to the prosecutrix's room, and one of them opened the door—I fitted this chisel to the marks on the box, which had been broken open—it corresponds exactly.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw people running, I was behind them; this man put out his foot, and I fell down.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Four Months.

2532.
MARY HUNT was indicted
for concealing the birth of a child.
NOT GUILTY .

2533.
JULIA SPILLER was indicted
for a like offence; to which she pleaded.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Six Months.

div0.p: First Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
2534.
PETER SMITH RHIND was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

2535.
GEORGE STRUTT was indicted
for assaulting
Esther Good
ing, with intent, &c.

GUILTY of an Assault.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2536.
THOMAS CLATWORTHY was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Recorder.

2537.
BENJAMIN FAULKNER was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of July, 37lbs. weight of potatoes, value 1s.; and 1 sack, value 4d.; the goods of
Samuel Mitchell, his master; to which he pleaded.

GUILTY .—
Confined Seven Days.

2538.
DENNIS CLEMENTS was indicted
for the wilful murder of
Bridget Holloway.
MR. BODKIN conducted the Prosecution.

SOPHIA VINCENT . I am the wife of Benjamin Vincent, of Smith's-rents, East-lane, Greenwich—I have lived there going on for four years—I knew Bridget Holloway, the deceased—she lived in the next room to me—mine is the front, hers was the back—a partition of wood separates our rooms—you can hear what passes from one room to the other—you can hear persons talk—the prisoner was in the habit of going to the room in which the deceased lived—I thought, at first, they were man and wife—he is a pensioner in the Hospital—on Sunday, the 10th of July, about nine o'clock at night, I was in my own room, and heard the cry of "Murder" coming from the deceased's room several times—I did not hear any other person but her—she continued to cry "Murder" several times, until the cries grew fainter—I went down and told Mrs. Smith, who was at the door—I then went back to my room, and heard no more noise, or cries that night—next day I went into Bridget Holloway's room, about half-past twelve—I brought her up some hot water—I found her sitting on her bed undressed, in her petticoat and shift—she told me she was very bad—she could hardly speak—she was obliged to stop two or three times between the words—she showed me her left side—it was all bruised black and discoloured—she said she should never get over it, for she was sure her ribs were broken—she appeared to be labouring under the impression that she should die—she said the prisoner had done it by constantly knocking her on the side—I saw her again on Tuesday evening, and then no more till after her death—she died on Thursday—about twelve o'clock on Tuesday night I was in my own room, and heard her groans—I never heard her any

more—she told me, on Tuesday, that she was a great deal worse, and she complained of her left side, that she could not lie—it was the same place she had pointed out to me before—on the Thursday after her death, I saw the prisoner at Dr. Mitchell's, and asked him if she had been worse the night before—he said no, she had been better—I said she could not be better, for she complained of being very bad—he then began to abuse me—I told him he had ill-used her—he denied it—I did not say anything about the cries I had heard, because Mr. Mitchell came in, and it was stopped—he went out.

Prisoner. Q. Did you ever see me drunk, or ill-use her? A. I have heard you ill-use her several times before—I was never in her room when you and she were there, but I have heard you ill-use her many a time with your tongue—I never saw you strike her.

SUSAN MARY MATTHEWS . I lived in this house. On Sunday night, the 10th of July, about nine o'clock, I saw the prisoner come out of the deceased's room—she called him an infernal rogue, and said he had done for her now—he had given her a death-blow—as he passed by the door. he made answer, "You infernal b—h, it serves you right."
Prisoner. Q. Did you hear me say so? A. Yes, I did—I saw you go down stairs—my door was open.
Prisoner. God forgive you! I made no answer.

SUSAN MART SMITH . I am the wife of Henry Smith, a shoemaker, and live in Smith's-rents, in the room under Bridget Holloway. On Sunday evening, the 10th of July, about eight o'clock, I was going down stairs, and met her on the stairs—she appeared to be as well as usual—the spoke to me—I do not know what age she was—she appeared about seventy—Mrs. Vincent came and told me something; that evening, in consequence of which, I went up into my own room, and heard the deceased crying bitterly, in her own room—I did not see her any more that night—about half-past eight in the morning, I heard her knocking in her room—I went out to see what it was, and then went up into her room—she was just sat down on the bed—she was alone—when she spoke she put her hand to her left side, and it was several seconds before she could speak—she showed me her bruises—I observed bruises on her side—she said she was sure her ribs were broken, and he had given her her death-blow—she had a bruise on each arm, a bruise on her breast, and a slight one on the leg, besides those on the side—I went up about one o'clock, and took her a little broth, thinking it might do her good—she seemed in more agonizing pain than before—she was in the habit of going into the streets with a basket, for the last eight months—she went out that afternoon, between three and four o'clock—I carried her basket down stairs for her—she seemed very bad, and still complained of being very ill, that he had given her her death
blow, and she should never get over it—she returned between six and seven—I saw her next day, Tuesday, between three and four in the after
noon—she appeared to be getting worse—I did not see her on Wednesday—I heard her in her room about half-past twelve at night, groaning very much indeed—on Thursday morning, about half-past seven, the prisoner opened my door, came in, and said, "She is gone; she is gone"—another person said directly, "Is she gone to the Union?"—he said, "No; she is dead, she is dead"—in consequence of that, I went up stairs into the room, and found her dead, but not quite cold—there was a bruise to be seen then on her side as she was lying—the prisoner said, "What do you think will be done in this case?"—I

said I did not know, it would appear very dark against him—he said, "The bruise was done by her daughter, some years ago"—I said "It would have been worn out before this time"—he made no answer to that—we all three then left the room.

Prisoner. Q. Did you see me come down stairs drunk while there, or abuse the woman, or kick up any noise all the time you had been there? A. No—I was never up in the room—I have heard that you ill-treated her very much before I went there—I never saw or heard you ill-use her—I never heard any quarrelling.

THOMAS OAK MITCHELL . I am a surgeon, and live at Greenwich. I knew the deceased before this occurred—I was called to see her after her death—the prisoner applied to me to give a certificate of the cause of death—I had attended the woman twelve months prior, for a rheumatic affection—at the time the prisoner called on me he stated that she had been in a very infirm state of health a long time—I left the room, to consult a medical report book—on my return, I found Mrs. Vincent there, and in consequence of hearing the word "ill-treatment" made use of, I refused the certificate—I afterwards, by the order of the Coroner, examined the body externally—it presented appearances of bruises, extending from the left shoulder, over the left side, nearly to the pelvis, and also marks of bruises on the right and left arm—four ribs were fractured, two of which were found penetrating a portion of the left lung, which, in my judgment, was the immediate cause of death—the most prominent symptom was the difficulty of breathing—a blow or a kick would most probably produce such an injury—it must have been very violent—I should say she had been suffering from the injury three or four days.

Prisoner. She had been under him once before with a very bad cough, and was ailing; she took liquor, and has fallen down stairs; it is not the first time I have taken her up stairs, bruised, and complaining of her side. Witness. I never attended her before with any complaint of that description—she was subject to rheumatic affection in the winter—the body was in other respects perfectly healthy—the fracture of the ribs was the cause of death, by producing inflammation of the lungs—I doubt whether, if it had been seen to in the first instance, that life could have been saved, from the position in which the ribs were, and the lung being lacerated—it might have given her a chance.

JOSEPH BERRIDGE . I am a surgeon. I assisted Mr. Mitchell in the post mortem examination—he has correctly stated the appearances of the body—I agree with him entirely in his opinion as to the cause of death.

JEREMIAH COOLAN . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into cus
tody on this charge, and told him I took him on suspicion of killing a woman—he said he was innocent—in taking him to the station, I asked him How the wounds were inflicted on the body—he said they were caused by falling down stairs.

Prisoner's Defence. Some friends from London came to see me, and after dinner we went to a public-house; the deceased drank with us all the afternoon; I went to see my friends off, and then went home; the old woman was pretty well, only had drank too much; I was sitting in my chair, when she took a start, and said, "I want some money;" I looked at her, and said, "I have got none to give you, you have had plenty to drink. without having any more;" she said, "You b—thief, if you don't give it to me I will knock you down;" she took up the hair-broom to give me

a knock on the head; she said, "I don't expect to live long, and I will leave you in trouble before I go;" I took the broom out of her hand, put it in the corner, and was going out, when she caught hold of my collar, dragged me back, and said, "You want to go out to your wh—s, you must give roe some money;" I said, "Let go;" she would not, but was drag
ging and striking me; I gave her a shove with one band, and she went back right against the bedstead; she screamed, "Murder!" I said, "Oh, you villain, this is what you wanted, to bring me into trouble;" I went out, and went to the College; I saw her next day, about two o'clock, sit
ting in the street with her basket, but never spoke to her, and on Tuesday morning I saw her in the same place; she shook her head and hand, and said, "You b—thief, I will fetch you in before I go, I know my time is not long;" she went up stairs, and breathed hard; she was a very un
healthy woman; I saw her again that night come out of a public-house; I paid her rent, but never lived with her, only for shame's take; the fol
lowed me from London; I gave her up several times, but she would come after me; I saw her several times on Wednesday; she seemed as well as ever, and I bought her sixpenny worth of cakes to sell next day; when I left her at night she told me to lock the door, and take the key with me, which I did, and went to the College; when I came, about seven o'clock next morning, she was in bed; that frightened roe, and I ran down and told the people that she was gone; they went up, and she had her hands clenched, as if she was in convulsions; I went and told Mr. Mitchell of it, he told me the Jury must sit on her, and I had her laid out.

GUILTY of Manslaughter. Aged 68.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Year.
Before Mr. Recorder.

2539.
SARAH WESTCOTT was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Richard Killick, about twelve o'clock in the night of the 30th of July, at
St. Paul, Deptford, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 1 pair of boots, value 2s., his property.

RICHARD KILLICK . I am a shoemaker, and live in the Broadway, in the parish of St. Paul, Deptford—I keep the house. On the 30th of July, about twenty minutes before twelve o'clock at night, I saw the prisoner at my window—she put her hand under her shawl, and deliberately hit a pane of glass, but did not break it—she then hit it again, broke it, and drew the boots through the window—I followed her out, and she dropped them just before I got hold of her—I saw one fall from her.

Prisoner. It was his wife laid hold of me; I slipped against the win
dow and broke it, but did not take the boots; he did not come out for five minutes. Witness. She took them, and they were thrown down at a distance from the window—my wife was going up stairs to bed at the time—I am quite sure it was a wilful act—the boots were picked up about five yards from the window—the prisoner has no mother, and I rather think she is not properly looked to.
JOHN WHITE . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner—I asked How she came to do it—she said she did not know—I took hold of her—she said, "Don't take hold of me, I will go with pleasure."
Prisoner. He said I was very foolish not to take a new pair, and asked

whether my father sent me to do it. Witness. I did not—they are second
hand.
Evidence for the Prisoner.

I am the prisoner's father and am a hair-dresser. I had sent her out on this Saturday night for half-an-ounce of pepper—she would only have to go round the corner, and not to pass the prosecutor's house—she has left me once or twice since Easter.

2540.
PATRICK BURNS was indicted
for unlawfully, maliciously, and feloniously assaulting
Michael Thomas Cannon, on the 11th of Au
gust, and cutting and wounding him in and upon the head and left hand, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

MICHAEL THOMAS CANNON . I am a policeman. On the 11th of Au
