gust, about four o'clock in the morning, I was on duty in Woolwich Road, and noticed the prisoner coming from Mr. Miles's garden—I followed him and asked what he did on the premises—he said he was on a spree all night—I told him to come off the premises, up the lane leading towards the road—he complained of thirst—I said he could get some water from the pump—he had no cap or stock on—he carried a stick in his right hand and a stone in his left—he is a soldier—I suspected he had been stealing the fruit, and told him to give the stick up, making an effort to take it from him, he up with the stick and struck me over the right shoulder, and again over the right temple—he said he thought I was one of the picquet, and was there to take him into custody—he struck me several times—I took my staff out, and then we exchanged several blows—we both fell on the ground—there was a piece of iron, about five inches long, at the end of the stick he struck me with—it is termed a chevaux-de-frise—he afterwards drove this part of the stick into my hand—I did not find any fruit upon him—he never gave any account why he was in the garden.

Prisoner. Q. Which end of the stick did I hit you with? A. With both—I have suffered in my hand and on my head ever since—I did not strike you till you had struck me four or five blows—I did not seize you by the breast before you struck me—you came from an enclosed garden or orchard, with fruit trees and vegetables in it.

GEORGE MATTISON . I am a labouring man. On the morning of the 11th of August, I was going towards Woolwich and saw the prisoner and prosecutor struggling in the road—I saw the prisoner give the policeman some heavy blows—the prisoner sprung up and tried to get the stave from his hand, and threw him down—the prisoner came again, and struck him on the head with the iron end of the stick—the prisoner was secured.

Prisoner. Q. How far off were you while I was engaged with him? A. Close to you at the last of it—I saw him knock the stick from your hand—he did not knock you down, he threw you down at last—you did not say to me, "Is a soldier to be murdered on the road?"—you said, "Civilian, I am killed"—I said, "Go quietly, I cannot help it."

JOHN TESTER (police-constable R 89.) On the morning of the 11th of August, I was on duty in Woolwich Road, the adjoining beat to the pro
secutor's—I saw him and the prisoner struggling on the road, and both bleeding—I took up the chevaux-de-frise—when I came up, he said to the prosecutor, "You b—, if I had known you were coming to assist him,

I would have murdered you when I had you down, I would have kicked you on the head;" and on his way to the station he said he would lay wait for him when he got at liberty, and would put an end to him some day, when he could make it convenient.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me lying down or sitting on the road? A. You went and sat down as I came up to you.

EDWARD DOWLING . I am surgeon to the police force at Greenwich. On the morning of the 11th of August, I examined the constable Cannon—he had a contused wound on the left side of the head, two on the right side, a contusion on the right temple, a wound on the hand, and other marks of violence on his body—I considered the wound on the hand very serious, there was a great deal of inflammation about the arm, it had wounded the ligaments, and appeared to be done with great force—the prisoner had a severe contused laceration, such as a policeman's staff would make—the policeman's wounds were such as the iron end of the instru
ment would make—I think his head and hands were struck with that end.

Prisoner's Defence. Coming out in the morning about four o'clock, over the gate of the place, the constable came up and said, "Where are you going?" I said, "What is that to you?" be said, "You must give an account of yourself; I said I was on a bit of a spree all night; he said, "Well, I have been an old soldier myself, and have had many a spree;" I laid hold of the handle of the pump; he laid hold of my hand, and said, "You must give up the stick; I said, "Why?" he said, "Come with me to the station;" I would not; he then up with his staff, and struck me; I said, "What would it be for a soldier to come along with a policeman?" and he then struck me before I struck him; he tore the breast of my shirt off; I said, "I am a-soldier, and will go to my bar
rack?;" he then struck me down; his wounds are not so much as they appear with that plaster over them; I picked the instrument up in the road.

MICHAEL THOMAS CANNON
re-examined. I did not lay hold of him at all till he struck me with the stick—this instrument is used at Wool
wich to fence in the cannon.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Years.
Before Mr. Baron Rolfe.

2541.
JOSEPH HUGHES was indicted
for feloniously uttering a forged receipt for 12l., knowing it to be forged, with intent to defraud
Samuel Burrows.
MR. PAYNE conducted the Prosecution.

MARGARET BURROWS . I am the wife of Samuel Burrows, who is now at sea. On the 8th of February I took a coffee-house of the prisoner, called The Arundel, at Greenwich—I agreed to pay 35l. a year—he was to be my lodger, and to occupy one bed-room, at 3s. a week, and to pay extra for what meals he had there—on the 3rd of May he made out this account, and delivered it to me—I think it she as 5l. 3s. 10d. owing to me—on the 8th of May a quarter's rent would become due, which was 8l. 15s., and on the 4th of July, a person was put into possession for it—on the 9th of July I signed an agreement to let it remain for three weeks—I have not got that agreement, I believe one of the condemning brokers has it—I do not know whether he is here—on the 3rd of August my demand against the prisoner was 14l. 5s. 3d.—on the 6th of August I

still owed him 8l. 15s. for a quarter's rent—there would be another quarter die pm the 8th pf August—on Saturday, the 6th of August, I met the prisoner at the office of Mr. Smith, a solicitor, at Green which, by appointment, for the purpose of settling the accounts between us, and whatever rent was due to him, I was willing and prepared to pay him by the Monday—14l. 15s. 3d. was due to me, and two quarters' rent to him—I should have had to pay him 2l. 14s. 9d.—when I met him at Mr. Smith's he produced this receipt for 12l., purporting to bear my signature—I had never signed it, nor ever saw it or knew of it till then—I never borrowed 12l. of the prisoner, nor ever had a fraction in the shape of money from him—he said it was for 12l. which he had paid me—a man named Tuck was produced for the prisoner before the Magistrate, as a witness to the money being paid—I think he was sworn.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. The prisoner was obliged to put in a distress on the 3rd of July? A. Because he did not pay his ac
counts—he put a distress in, and took it off on my promising to pay—I did not pay at that time—I have not had a great many disagreements with people about payments—I cannot tell How many—I do not know whether Mr. Smith is here—I have not brought him here—the first bro
ker employer when this distress was put in was Mr. Parker—I did not see Mr. Dunford on that occasion—since the second distress I did—at that time the prisoner owed me nearly 15l.—I have the account here—I told Mr. Dunford that—that I swear—the second distress was made on the 9th of August—Mr. Dunford was there when the first distress was made—he was one of the condemning brokers—Parker was the distrain
ing broker—I did not see Mr. Dunford on the second occasion, nor on any other occasion than the one I have spoken of—a man named Maberley was the broker on the second occasion—I never charged other people with forging receipts—that I swear—I know Mary Andrews and her husband signed it or not I do not know, and therefore I could not charge him with it—I never threatened to charge him with forging a receipt—that I swear—I never threatened to charge him with forging my name to a receipt of 3l. at the Custom-house—there was a book produced which was receipted, but I never charged him with doing it—I never charged or threatened to charge him with forging my name—I never gave him a receipt in pencil for that 3l.—I cannot tell How often I have been at the Police-office at Greenwich—it might be often—I have gone when I have had occasion to go—I cannot tell you How often—I cannot tell whether I have been there twenty times, thirty times, or forty times—I do not know at all—I cannot tell whether I have not been forty times before the Justice, making charges against individuals—I will not swear that I have not made forty charges against forty different individuals there—I charged a man once with not paying for refreshments which he had at my house—he said he had paid me, but he had not—I charged him with an assault, but it originated in my not being paid—I was on that occasion charged with kicking a man in a certain place—I was not fined—I had to pay 10s.—I do not know whe
ther I was fined, or whether it was the expenses—I preferred an indict
ment against a man for perjury, after being before the Justice—the bill was not thrown out—I did not come into the witness box—the man was never tried—I never said to Mr. Dunford since I preferred this charge, that for 10l. I would squash this indictment, nor that I would make a

flaw in it—I never said, "If Hughes will give up the note, and pay me the difference I won't hurt him"—nor if I had 10l. from him I would go into the country and squash the concern—I never said so to any body—I did not say, "You know, Mr. Dunford, a word before the Grand Jury will do it"—I did not after the prisoner was in charge go to Sergeant Good and tell him I suspected he had committed a murder—I did not tell him there was a smell in the room, and I believed a murder had been committed there—I did not say so to Arthur—I said, there was a very offensive smell in the room, something I could not possibly make out, and re
quested their interference—I said it was certainly like a dead body, or something of that kind—it was a very unnatural smell—I never said to Good, or Arthur that I believed there was a murdered man in the pri
soner's room—I remember seeing Good and Arthur when I was in com
pany with the witness Weale—Arthur did not on that occasion tax me with having taken a false oath before the Magistrate—I did not say I had done so to save myself the trouble I had got into, that I had got into trouble enough about this business already, and I did not want any more—I never alluded to a false oath—nothing of the sort occurred.

MR. PATNE. Q. Have you ever on any occasion, when you have gone before a Magistrate, made a false or incorrect charge? A. Not that I know of—I have always strictly stated the truth—I have not kept an account of the number of times, I have had occasion to take people be
fore a Magistrate, or to go before a Magistrate—I should say I have not been forty times before a Magistrate.

JOHN HEALEY . I am a solicitor, and live in Keppel-street, Black
friars-road—I have known Mrs. Burrows rather more than eleven years, and am very well acquainted with her hand-writing—I have seen this re
ceipt before, at Mr. Smith's office, and before the Magistrate—the words "Mergret Burrows," and the name above that, is certainly not in her handwriting—the body of it the prisoner says be wrote himself—the name if Dot at all like her writing—she cannot write so well—I never saw any so good.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Why, is that not very bad? A. It is not good—I have seen a good deal worse—I am not practising as an attorney for myself, and have not for the last sixteen years—I have not taken out my certificate—I have been acting at clerk in other offices, but I am a solicitor—I last saw Mrs. Burrows write about a week or ten days ago, and I had seen her write a day or two before the charge was made before the Magistrate—she has consulted me on every occasion where, she has been in trouble since her husband went away—in the early part of the time I was acquainted with her she consulted me as regarded her property, previous to her marriage, and subsequently she has consulted me very often indeed, with regard to this business at Greenwich, I mean the business between her and the prisoner—not about this note—I was not her attorney in the assault cases—I never went to the police-court at Greenwich on her account—she consulted me upon that, and I advised her to go to Mr. May, and take him with her—I have never been there with her—I am not the attorney for this prosecution.

ELIZA WEALE . I have lived for several months with Mrs. Burrows, as
sisting her in her business at Greenwich, since last Easter. On the 4th of July, a distress was put into the house for rent, and a second distress was put in this month—on the first occasion I heard her say to the prisoner "It

is very hard that you should distrain on me for rent, knowing that you owe me more for board and lodging"—he said, "I will have my rent, you may get what I owe you in the best way you can"—I never heard him men
tion a sum of 12l. that he had lent or paid her, or anything of the kind.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Were they not quarrelling? A. Yes—it was on the Saturday before the first distress—I heard Mrs. Burrows ask the prisoner to come to terms on the Monday that the distraint was put in, and several times.
MR. PAYNE. Q. The conversation took place on the Monday, and the quarrel on the Saturday? A. Yes.

GEORGE GOOD (police-sergeant R 2.) The prisoner was given into my custody by Mrs. Burrows, at the coffee-shop, on Tuesday, the 9th of Au
gust, for forging a receipt—I asked him to produce the receipt, that I might show it to her—he refused to do so—he went up stairs—I followed him, and Mrs. Burrows came immediately after me—I did not see her till I got into the room—I went in after the prisoner—I asked him to let me see the receipt, so that Mrs. Burrows might see it—he said he was advised not to show it, and would not show it any more—I had seen it before—he afterwards pulled it out, and laid it on the table—while it was on the table, Mrs. Burrows came in—she said that it was a forgery, it was not hers, she had never seen it before till she had seen it at Mr. Smith's office—the prisoner took it off the table and put it into his pocket—I took him into custody, found the receipt on him, took possession of it, and have produced it to-day—the prisoner called a man named Tuck, as a witness, before the Magistrate.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. He did not object to show you the receipt? A. He did at first—he would not show it to me before Mrs. Burrows, but I had seen it before—he showed it to me, with the broker, when Mrs. Burrows was not present—I remember being in company with Mrs. Burrows and the witness Weale, in the presence of Arthur, a police-constable, a day or two after I had taken the prisoner—we were in a room in Mrs. Burrows' coffee-house—Arthur said that she had taken a false oath before the Magistrate, and she said she believed she had—that was allud
ing to Eliza Weale—I do not remember her saving she had done so to save herself trouble, that she had got into trouble enough already—that might have been said—she said she believed she had taken a false oath—I remember the prosecutrix telling me, after the prisoner was given into cus
tody, that she suspected there was a murdered man in the prisoner's room—she came to the station, and said there was a dreadful stench in the room which the prisoner occupied, and she believed there was something there which should not be, that it smelt as if some dead body was in the room.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Who was present when this matter about the false oath took place? A. Mrs. Burrows, Mr. Dunford, Arthur, and myself and Mr. Davis—it was at the time I went to see what caused the stench—I believe Mrs. Burrows and Arthur began the conversation—I cannot tell what was first said—I did not take particular notice what it was all about—it was respecting some woman she had had taken up a day or two be
fore—I believe the false oath was in reference to that woman—Arthur said he thought that Eliza Weale had taken a false oath, not that Mrs. Burrows had—that is what I mean, and that was what I said before—Arthur said to Mrs. Burrows that Eliza Weale had taken a false oath be
fore
the Magistrate—I did not understand him to say that Mrs. Burrows had—Arthur is here.

(Receipt read)—"Received, July 2, 1842, from Mr. Joseph Hughes, the sum of 12l. for board and lodging, from Feb. 8, 1842, to Aug. 9, 1842, which sum pays for lodging and board only to that time, Aug. 9, 1842, and all meals had between the date of this receipt and the said Aug. 9th to be paid for on delivery, which J. A. agrees to. My husband, Samuel Burrows, being at sea, has authorised me, Mergrat Burrows, to pay and receive his accounts; and I further agree to pay Mr. Joseph Hughes 18d. per week for the loan of a bedstead, bed, wool palliasse, pillows and appertenances, from April 5, 1842.—Mergrat Burrows, as per receipt above, for board and lodging, 12l.—Mergrat Bur"—(the remainder of the name was torn or burnt off.)

MRS. BURROWS re-examined. I always spell my name Margaret—I never signed my name at the bottom of a blank piece of paper with a stamp on it—I never signed my name to any paper for the prisoner, the corner of which was burnt off, and then signed it again—I never gave him a receipt of any kind—I never received 12l. from him, nor any money whatever, not a farthing.

HENRY DUNFORD . I am an auctioneer and house-agent, and live at Greenwich. I know the prosecutrix from a very slight acquaintance since the 9th of July—I was employed in the first distress at that time, as the appraiser—about the 10th or 11th of this month I saw her at her own house—she said to me, "If Hughes will give up the receipt and pay me the difference, I won't hurt him; if Hughes behaves well to me, and I have 10l., I will go into the country and squash the concern"—I cannot say that she said, "You know, Mr. Dunford, a word before the Grand Jury will do it"—this was at the second distress—she never told me that the prisoner owed her 12l.—I was present when the agreement was made to redeem the goods—that was the time this occurred.

MR. PAYNE. Q. When was this conversation between you and Mrs. Bur
rows? A. On the 9th, 10th, or 11th of August—I did not take particular notice—I had occasion to go there—I had a conversation with her respect
ing the moving a sippy-table, and in the conversation this came out.
(The Jury, on examining the date on the stamp, stated it to be 18—7, meaning the 18th of 7 th mouth, July, which was subsequent to the date of the receipt.)

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Two Years.
Before Edward Bullock, Esq.

2542.
MARY POWELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of August, 3 pairs of stockings, value 6s.; 1 scarf, value 5s.; 6 handker
chiefs, value 1l. 17s. 6d.; 9 napkins, value 9s.; 1 towel, value 1s.; 1 yard of muslin, value 1s.; 2 pairs of drawers, value 5s.; 1 pincushion cover, value 1s.; and 1 yard of lace, value 1s.; the goods of
Richard Stewart Evelyn Forster, clerk, her master.
MR. DOANE conducted the Prosecution.

ABABELLA CROW . I am in the service of the Rev. Mr. Forster—the prisoner was his housekeeper—he was in Lincolnshire at the latter end of May—the prisoner went down there, and returned about the 24th of June

—some time after I saw in her conduct something that excited my suspi
cion—on Sunday, the 31st of July, I went up stairs to her bed-room door, I found it was locked and the key talc en away, which was unusual—I got a key and opened it, and in the room I found some drawers trim
med with lace, and some other articles which I did not believe were the prisoner's—on the 6th of August I told my master and mistress of it.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long had you been in the service? A. Two years and three months—the prisoner was put as housekeeper over me—I did not dislike that—I have expressed some dis
like because I saw some things which were not proper—I did not go to Lincolnshire this year—the prisoner went with the family, leaving me be
hind—I opened the prisoner's room door, because I thought things were not right—I had not mentioned it to my master or mistress before—they were not in the house—I had been suspecting things were not right for about three weeks—I never said I would get the prisoner transported nor anything of the kind, nor that I wished she might be transported—I never said anything about it, nor heard anything said about it, before she was taken, and then Bodley, my fellow-servant, said she deserved to be trans
ported.
MR. DOANE. Q. Was it a false key with which you opened the door of the prisoner's room? No, the key of the next room door.

MARY BODLEY . I am servant to Mr. Forster—I had only been there about two months—I observed the prisoner to lock her room door, and she was the only person who did so—on the 7th of August I observed her go towards the water-closet several times within a short period, and as she went on one occasion I observed a piece of muslin hanging from the pocket
hole of her dress—I then went into the water-closet and searched—I found some muslin, a cap border, and some other articles—they were cleansed and shown to my master and mistress.

Cross-examined. Q. Who directed your attention to the prisoner as she was going to the water-closet? A. No one—Crow was then gone to church—it was Crow who told me the prisoner's locking her door was unusual—I went into the water-closet immediately after the prisoner came out—I was standing on the stain as she came out—I found the articles down the pan quite concealed, so that they would have been destroyed—Crow and I had been talking about this a few evenings before that—I forget whether Crow told me that she had opened the prisoner's room door with another key—she said she went into her room when she was gone to church—I do not know when my master returned from Lin
colnshire—I was not then in the service—I said I thought the prisoner deserved to be transported, as Crow said she had things belonging to her master and mistress—we were all bound to tell our mistress.
MR. DOANE. Q. How soon did you tell your mistress? A. On the Monday, the next day.

JOHN DUNCAN . I have been in the service of the Rev. Mr. Forster for twenty-two years. On Monday, the 8th of August, I was requested by him to go up stairs to the prisoner's room—I went up, and found the pri
soner, and the ladies'-maid, there—I told the prisoner she had got some of Mr. Forster's property, and to take all the things out of her box, and lay them on the bed—she did so—I then said she had better put her own things back, and give Mr. Forster's things to me—she then gave me these things—I told her to look her own things up, and we should be
obliged to tend for a policeman—I sent for the officer, and delivered the things the prisoner had given me as belonging to my master.
Cross-examined. Q. Where were the things when you went up? A. In her box—she had the lid open, and was at the things.
WILLIAM SMITH (police-constable R 254.) I took the prisoner, and have the things I received from Duncan.

REV. STEWART EVELYN FORSTER . I am a clergyman of the Church of England, and reside at Lewishan. I had occasion to go into Lincolnshire, where I had resigned two livings which I held there—I had a sister died a short time before, (Mrs. Charles Forster,) and I bad a box which contained various articles of hers, which were kept in Lincolnshire for a niece of hers—I took the prisoner down for the purpose of packing up the wearing-ap
parel, which I was removing from there to my present residence—she had access to every thing—in consequence of what my servants told me, I sent Duncan up stairs, and be produced these things—I can speak to these stock
ings very particularly, knowing them to have belonged to my brother—they were marked "C F"—I can see that the C has been taken out, and in this instance the stalk of the "F" is of a different colour to the new work—the box from which these were taken contained other articles of a similar description—this handkerchief I can identify, as being a handsome handkerchief—I have one from the box like it—I cannot say How many there were, but I can say that several have been abstracted—the box is much, lower than it was, in respect to the qnantity of things it contains—these other articles I cannot speak to—here are handkerchiefs which have been recently marked "M P"—they have been lying some time in the box, and they correspond.

Cross-examined. Q. Which are the articles you identify? A. These three pairs of stockings, and the bottoms of these two pain of ladies' drawers—they were the bottom of a baby's robe—it was chiefly baby-linen that was in that box, except pocket-handkerchiefs and stockings—I saw them in the box on the 14th or 15th of June, and I left Lincolnshire about the 20th—I did not take an inventory, nor count the articles in it—I looked in, but did not ascertain whether any articles were missing—I never gave the prisoner any stockings for herself—I gave her some for the narsery-maid, but they were marked with different initials—the box came from Lincolnshire with the rest of my things—I saw all the articles as soon as they arrived at my house—the prisoner was in my service eight months, as cook and housekeeper—she came from Mrs. Barr's boarding-house, at Cheltenham.
MR. DOANE. Q. Did you ever give her stockings of this description? A. No—I never gave her these drawers which are trimmed with lace—she had no right to have touched them.

ELIZABETH NEATH . I am lady's-maid to Mrs. Forster. I remember Duncan coming into the prisoner's room—I have heard the account he has given—it is correct—the fringe that is sewn on to the bottom of this scarf I had missed—it was some that belonged to my master—since the things came from Lincolnshire, I have missed napkins similar to these—I be
lieve them to be the same—there has been "C F" marked on them—it is picked out, but the remains of it is quite plain.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you go up before Duncan? A. I went up with him—I do not know whether I went into the room before him.

JANE BROWN . My husband is the prosecutor's coachman. I remem
ber
the prisoner's returning from Lincolnshire—she came to me soon after for my child to mark and sew for her—I consented to it—I saw my daughter in her room marking the things.
MARY BROWN . I went to the prisoner's room, at Mr. Forster's to mark the things—I marked some stockings, and some other things with the letters "M P."

MRS. FORSTER. I had some fringe of a rose colour—I had it dyed black—it did not take very well—I believe this fringe on this scarf to be part of that fringe—I missed a silk hat-band of my husband's, and this scarf has been a hat-band, I have no doubt—it is a peculiar kind of silk, and here are the remains of "C F" on these napkins, and "M P" is on them now.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose you scarcely speak with certainty to this fringe? A. Yes, I do—I saw it not many days before I left Lincoln
shire—it is worth 4s. or 5s.—it was packing up when I was going from Lincolnshire—on the 6th of August the prisoner came to me, and asked me to search her boxes, and they were searched.
MR. DOANE. Q. Do you find the remains of the rose-colour on this identical fringe? A. I do—I did not authorise her to take any of these things.

GUILTY. Aged 28.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury .—
Confined Twelve Months.
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2543.
HANNAH SHEARING was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of August, 1 towel, value 1s.; 1 flat-iron, value 1s.; 1 petticoat, value 1s. 6d.; and 1 table-cloth, value 6s.; the goods of
Charlotte Davis: to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Ten Days.

2544.
MARY LUNN was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of August, 2 gowns, value 5s.; and 1 petticoat, value 4s.; the goods of
Eliza Har
per; and 1 gown, value 3s., the goods of
Louisa Matthews.

CATHERINE RAWLEY . There was a fire at Deptford on the 9th of Au
gust, and I saw the prisoner take a bundle from the premises of Mrs. Gill—I set Edward Smith to watch her.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What time of day was it? A. About eleven o'clock in the morning—I have known the prisoner by sight—her husband is dead, and she has a family—she took these things out of a garden, where they were thrown for safety.
EDWARD SMITH . I watched the prisoner—she took the bundle to a shop in Church-street.
RUTH HARPER . I keep a shop in Church-street. The prisoner came and asked me to let her leave this bundle there—I gave it to the officer.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you known her? A. Yes, for ten years.
WILLIAM SHUTTLE WORTH (police-constable R 133.) I produce the bundle, which contains these articles, which I got from Mrs. Harper.
LOUISA MATTHEWS . This gown is mine—it was at Mrs. Gill's to be mangled.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know this petticoat? A. Yes—it is my mistress's sister's.
SARAH HARE . I found the petticoat on the prisoner's person.
MARY GILL . I am a laundress. These things were at ray house—they belonged to Eliza Harper and Louisa Matthews—I think the prisoner was in very great distress.

GUILTY. Aged 40.—Recommended to mercy by the jury .—
Confined Ten Days.

2545.
ANTHONY BURNHAM and
MARTHA BURNHAM were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of May, 1 bed, value 3l.; 1 bolster, value 6s.; 2 blankets, value 13s.; and 1 sheet, value 6s.; the goods of
Thomas Seers, the master of Anthony Burnham.

DOROTHY SEERS . I am the wife of Thomas Seers, the master of Anthony Burnham. These articles were in a cottage, which was not ours, but the articles were—the servant saw them there safe last November—they are here, and are ours.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. I believe you and your husband kept the Tiger's Head at Lee? A. Yes—we left It two years ago, and then we removed these things to the cottage, which we hired for the pur
pose of putting these things in—we had the key generally, but Anthony Burnham had it occasionally, to go there for different things—he and his wife lived near there—this bolster is my own making, and this bed was made by myself and servants—here is a small hole in this bolster, about sufficient for a pea to pass through—I made the bolster perhaps fourteen or fifteen years ago—I know the ticking of this bed perfectly, and part of my own work is on it—Anthony Burnham has been in our service about twelvemonths.
MARY WINCE . I am in the prosecutors, service. I saw the property safe in the cottage about six months ago.

JOHN CARPENTER (police-constable R 84.) I went to the prisoner's house, and found Martha Burnham there—it has been rumoured that she is not the wife of Anthony Burnham—I found this bed and bolster there—she said she bought it seven years ago; after that, that it was given her by her mother; and after that, that she bought the tick of a tally man, and the feathers were given her by her mother.

WILLIAM KIRBY (police-constable R 22.) I went to the prisoner's house with Carpenter, and saw Martha Burnham attempt to conceal something in a black bag—I took the bag from her, and found in it six duplicates, one of which is for a blanket pawned on the 7th of May, which has been identified by Mrs. Seers—I then went after Anthony Burnham—I asked if he had heard any thing from Lee—he said, "No"—I told him Martha Burnham was taken, and cautioned him as to what he said—he said, "Pretty doirgs these are"—he said he had had the bed some years, that he bought it of a man named Distant, who had lived in Theobald's-road some years ago, but was since dead.
EDWARD NASH . I am a pawnbroker. This blanket was pawned by Martha Burnham, on the 7th of May.
MRS. SEERS. This is my blanket—I am able to swear to it.
Cross-examined. Q. How do you know it? A. By its being like the one I lost—I have no mark on it.

ANTHONY BURNHAM—
GUILTY. Aged 40.—Recommended to mercy .

—
Confined Three Months.

MARTHA BURNHAM—
NOT GUILTY .

2546.
RICHARD BATCHELOR was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of August, 1 watch, value 80s.; 1 watch-key, value 2d.; and 1 watch-ribbon, value 4d.; the goods of
Richard Riley Edney; and 2 handkerchiefs, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
Elizabeth Edney; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 48.—
Confined Six Months.

2547.
JOHN SMALE and
RICHARD RIVERS were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of July, 6 tame rabbits, price 12.s., the property of
William Pershouse, the younger; and that Smale had been before con
victed of felony.

WILLIAM PERSHOUSE, JUN . I live with my father, who is a farmer at Greenwich. On the 20th of July I had six tame rabbits in a butch it three o'clock in the afternoon, and at six o'clock the next morning I missed them—I have seen them since—these are them—they are mine—Smile worked for my father.

JOHN ROWSELL . I live in Edward-street, Woolwich, and deal in rab
bits. About half-past eight o'clock in the morning of the 21st of July, the prisoners came to me, and I bought these rabbits of them.

GEORGE SALE (police-constable R 174.) On the 22nd of July I appre
hended the prisoner Smale—I told him what it was for—be said he knew nothing about it—I took him to the prosecutor—he told Mr. Pershouse where the rabbits were—he told me—I went and got them.
BENJAMIN LOVELL . I produce a certificate of Smale's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

SMALE—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

RIVERS—
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Three Months.

2548.
SARAH SCUDDER was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of July, 1 watch, value 7l.; 1 ribbon, value 1s.; 3 seals, value 2l.; 1 key, value 6d.; the goods of
John Black, from his person.

JOHN BLACK . I live in Salisbury-street, Strand. On the 9th of July, I was in the Lewisham-road, Greenwich—I had been dining at Blackwall, and was going home a little heated with wine—the prisoner was standing at the corner of a court—she hailed me, and asked me for money—I gave her either one or two sixpences—the policeman came up and she darted off—he ran after her—I felt and ray watch was gone—this now produced is it.
SAMUEL ARGENT (police-constable R 54.) I saw the prisoner run up Lewisham-lane—I ran after her, and took this watch, ribbon, seals, and key from her bosom.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Nine Months.
Before Edward Bullock, Esq.

2549.
DANIEL BOYD was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of July, 2 pairs of trowsers, value 1l. 16s., and 1 waistcoat, value 1l. 4s.; the goods of a man whose name is unknown.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Mark Wells.

SARAH WELLS . I am the wife of Mark Wells, who keeps the Red Cow, in Old King-street, Deptford—I had some trowsers and other things in my care, about six months ago, left by Charles Price, who was mate of a vessel—I put them into a carpet bag, and kept them into a bed-chamber in my house—I missed them on the 29th of July—I know they were safe on

the Sunday before that—on the 28th the prisoner, who I had not known before, came intoxicated and requested a bed for the night, and he had one—he slept in a back room—he went to bed about four o'clock in the after
noon, and rose about twelve the next day—this bag and pair of trowsers were on a box in his room.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. Was not he very drank? A. Not so drunk but he could walk up stairs—my husband was aroused by him about three o'clock in the morning to get him some ale or beer—Mr. Price was the chief officer of the Maitland, which is gone to China—I have seen him wear these trowsers many times—I saw them safe on the 24th, and on the 29th I missed them—the door was not kept locked, but I have no one in the house—these are like the trowsers that were there, bat I would not swear to anything that is not mine.

JAMES KNIGHT (police-constable R 308.) I apprehended the prisoner and took him to the station—Mr. Wells made the charge against him—the sergeant cautioned him, that whatever he said would be used against him—he said, "I have stolen the things, and thrown them in the mouth of the cuddy."

Cross-examined. Q. What time of day was this? A. About a quarter before nine in the evening—I could not say he was drunk—I did not write down the words he said—we did not say it would be better to tell the truth—I went and found these articles in the boatswain's chest, in the cuddy—here are two pairs of trowsers and a waistcoat.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Baron Rolfe.

2550.
JAMES WHITTLE and
GEORGE WHITE
were indicted, for that they, on the 3rd of August, upon
John Hoare, did feloniously make an, assault, and put him in fear and danger of his life, and take from his per
son, and against his will, 1 watch, value 3l. 18s.; 1 watch-chain, value 2d.; 1 watch-key, value 1d.; 1 seal, value 1d.; 1 knife, value 1s.; 1 to
bacco-box, value 6d.; 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; and 6 halfpence; his property: and immediately before, at the time, and immediately after the said robbery, did cut and wound him.
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN HOARE . I am a gardener, living near Borstall-bill, in the parish of Plumstead, in Kent. On Wednesday, the 3rd of August, between twelve and one o'clock in the morning, I was going towards my cottage—I met two men—I should not know them again—they knocked me down—I felt them take something from me, but I soon lost my senses—when I came to my senses I missed my watch, knife, handkerchief, tobacco-box, and threepence-halfpenny in copper—I had been at a public-house—I was sober—I saw my watch again on the 4th of August, a person belonging to the 73rd regiment showed it me—I saw the handkerchief again that day week—I had been drinking for three hours at the public-house—I had last seen my watch at past twelve o'clock—that public-house was about half a mile from my house—this happened in the parish of Plumstead.
Whittle. Q. Can you say I am the person that robbed you? A. No.

GEORGE BAKER (police-constable R 60.) I was on duty on Tuesday night, the 2nd of August, and about half-past eleven o'clock I saw the two prisoners quarrelling by the Arsenal wall—I told them if they did not go away I should have to go and fetch the piquet—Whittle said they were

going for a country walk, down to the Green Man, at Plumstead—I saw them go in the direction for Plumstead—I saw them again at half-past six on the following morning, very near the Standard, in Woolwich—I only know them by seeing them about the street at various times—I have no doubt as to their being the persons.

Whittle. Q. What time did you see me first? A. I had seen you se
veral nights.

MARY ANDERSON . I live in Woolwich. On Tuesday, the 2nd of August, the two prisoners were in the Royal Standard skittle-ground, at Woolwich, playing at skittles—they went into a public-house—I staid there till the house was shut up—I went in at four o'clock, and left about half-past ten—they were there all that time—about seven the next morning I went to the same public-house, and found the prisoners there—Whittle asked me whether I would show them where the pawn-shop was—he said he wanted to go and pawn his watch—I went with them as far as the pawnbroker's door—Whittle went in, and White stopped outside—I returned to the public-house again, after that, with them, and staid there till eleven o'clock, when a piquet came to take them away.

CHARLES HIRONS (police-constable R 228.) I was in duty in Wool
wich about ten minutes to five o'clock in the morning of the 3rd of Au
gust—I saw the prisoners in Nightingale-vale, coming from Plumstead
common—White asked me which was the way to Woolwich—they had turned up a wrong turning, and came back—I am quite sure they are the two men.

PATRICK COLEMAN . I am a private in the 73rd Regiment of Foot On Wednesday evening, the 3rd of August, I was sentry at the Royal Artillery Barracks at Woolwich—I saw Harris search Whittle—I got a handkerchief from White, and asked him if it was his—he said no—I asked him if it belonged to his comrade—he said no—I kept it—this is it—(producing it)—the duplicate of a watch was found on Whittle—White was in con
finement, under military punishment—the prisoners were privates in the 73rd Regiment, which has been at Woolwich seven or eight months—I never saw the prisoners till that time, to my knowledge.

GEORGE HARRIS (police-constable R 158.) In consequence of some information, on the afternoon of Wednesday, the 3rd of August, I went to the barracks, and took Whittle into custody—I told him he was charged with robbing a man of his watch, and assaulting him on the Queen's high
way—he said he was quite innocent of the charge—I searched him, and found, in his left-hand trowsers' pocket, the duplicate of a watch, pawned for 20s.—I said, "Here is a duplicate, what duplicate is this?"—he said, "It is my own watch, I have had it for a long time"—I found two handkerchiefs on him—(one was very bloody indeed, which I found in his breast,) and 4s. 6d. in silver—I then went in search of White—I found him in a bed half an hour after—I searched him, and found on him a comb and a hand
kerchief.

MICHAEL BROWN (police-inspector R.) The prisoners were brought to me, on the evening of the 3rd of August, at the station—I read the charge to them, which was for robbing a man—White said, in answer to the corporal who brought him from the barracks, that he left Whittle at half-past eleven o'clock, and then he had no watch—he said he slept in the same house, at Woolwich, but he could not tell where that was—Whittle's hands were all over blood—I asked him about it, and he said it was blood from his nose—his trowsers were very much stained with blood—there was a particular
stain about the right knee, as though he had been kneeling down, and some marks of blood on the left knee of them.

White. He has said things I never said; I said no such words. Wit
ness. Yes, he did, in the presence of the corporal—I believe Harris heard the same words.

ROBERT HUNTER . I live with Mr. Moore, a pawnbroker, at Woolwich. Whittle pledged this watch at our shop about eight o'clock in the morning of the 3rd of August—I gave him this duplicate—it is pledged in his own name, for 1l., and the number of his regiment is put, the "73rd"—this is what he described himself.

THOMAS WRIGHT . I am a surgeon, at Woolwich. Early in the morn
ing of the 3rd of August, I examined the prosecutor, and found him in a weak state from the loss of blood—I found the mark of a blow on his forehead, which I should say was inflicted with the fist—there was only one mark, but it was of very considerable size—there was blood on his face—the hair of his head was completely matted with blood, and there was a wound on the back part of the head, between the ears—the blood might have come from that wound—it was a wound about two inches in length—it appeared to have been made with a bludgeon, or it might possibly have been a kick—there were no other wounds.
JURY. Q. Could that wound arise from a fall backwards? A. Yes, but it appeared as if it had been from a blow with a stick.
COURT. Q. Was it such a cut as might have resulted not from a blow at all, but from a blow in the front knocking him down? A. Decidedly not.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Whittle's Defence. The watch I had was mine, and I have had it eight or nine years; I am innocent.
White. I hope you will have mercy on me; I am innocent.

WHITTLE—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

WHITE—
GUILTY . Aged 25.

2551.
JOHN SAMUEL HARRIS was indicted
for feloniously mar
rying
Elizabeth Thomas, his former wife being still living.

The name of the second wife being
Elizabeth TEMS , the prisoner was
ACQUITTED.

2552.
HERBERT GOMPERTZ was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of June, 1 sovereign, 4 half-crowns, 6 sixpences, 36 pence, and 134 halfpence, the monies of
Robert Henry Davies, his master.

HOBERT HENRY DAVIES . I live in Fletcher-row, Clerkenwell. In June last I kept a beer-shop at Vauxhall—the prisoner was in the habit of com
ing there—on the 26th of June I left him in charge of the premises between two and three o'clock, locked the desk, took the key with me, and left the money stated in the indictment, safe—I went out to tea and left him to mind the business; his master, next door, being a pious man, I thought I could entrust him—I returned at half-past ten in the evening—I found

no gas alight and the place locked up—I was obliged to get through the next house to get in—I found two policemen at the door, and the key of the gas-meter box taken out and used to force open the desk, and the mo
ney gone—a pair of scissors had also been used—I found the key in the desk bent—he never returned—he was apprehended a month afterwards.
Prisoner. He forced the desk open himself, a week before, when he lost the key. Witness. I did not—I never lost the key.

Prisoner. The prosecutor was aware I was going down to the country on Monday; he only left 29s. 6d. in the desk for change, and left the key in it; he has got up this prosecution to extort money; he has endeavoured to get my friends to advance money—my brother gave him 3s.—he owed his brewer 3l. 4s., and asked me to take out a loan in my name, and I should have half of it; he said as I was going to leave, they could not come on me for payment, and as he was going to leave, they would not find him; I refused. Witness. It is not so—out of feeling towards his father and mother I would not bring them as witnesses—the prisoner was appre
hended at the workhouse when he came there—he was very badly off before this, he wanted shoes—I said if he chose to get a loan I would be security for 5l., but would not allow him to have more than half the money until I saw How he went on—it was to get him clothes, as I knew if he got sixpence he would spend it in drink—he had 12s. a-week from his master—the loan was to be for himself—I took the key of the desk with me—I also lost money from the till.

AGATHA BECKMAN . I live in Vauxhall-street—I went to Davies's house for a pot of beer about three o'clock—the prisoner served me—I saw the desk open then—he said he was going to enjoy himself—when I came out he shut the door after me—it was open before.
WELLINGTON WEBSTER . I am a policeman—I took the prisoner into custody on the 26th of July—he admitted taking 29s. from the desk, but disputed the full amount.

Prisoner. Q. Did not I say there was but 29s. left in the desk, with
out admitting taking any? A. You said you took 29s.—I am certain I found the desk broken open when I was sent for—a pair of scissors and a key were given me, with which it appeared to have been forced open—the prisoner said the prosecutor was never worth 3l., but he admitted tak
ing the money.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Six Mouths.
Before Edward Bullock, Esq.

2553.
EDWARD HUGHES was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of August, 1 hand-barrow, value 1l.; 300 herrings, value 10s.; 2 baskets, value 1s.; the goods of
Samuel Jones, his master; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

SAMUEL JONES . I deal in coals, and live in Neptune-street, New
ington—on the 4th of August I employed the prisoner, who said he was in distress, to take out some herrings to sell—I gave him a barrow with 300 herrings to sell—he was to account for them—I gave him sixpence the night before to get victuals with, as he said he was in distress, and I gave him another sixpence when he went away with the barrow and herrings—he never brought them or the money back—I saw nothing more of him until he was in custody on the 13th—on the 19th, since he was committed, the barrow has been left at my house.
Prisoner. You agreed to lend me the money and was to go partners with me; I was to go and sell the things. Witness. I employed you, and was to pay you for your day's work when you returned.

JAMES BROOK . I am a policeman—I took the prisoner in charge on Saturday the 13th—I told him the charge—he said he sent the barrow home by a boy they called "Fishey," that he sold the herrings for 10s.—he said the boy's father worked at the gas-woks—I inquired there, and found the boy is about eight years old.

Prisoner's Defence. I returned the barrow on Monday evening by a boy who is eighteen years of age; he could not find the house out—I was remanded when I was taken, but could not find him—my brother has since found him and returned the barrow to Mr. Jones.

EDWARD ELLIOTT . I am a policeman. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from the office of the Clerk of the Peace for Surrey—(read)—I was present at the trial—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY .* Aged 27.—
Confined Twelve Months.
Before Mr. Recorder.

2554.
HENRY TAYLOR was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Patrick Keefe, on the 31st of July, putting him in bodily fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, I watch, value 1l. 8s.; 1 watch-key, value 6d.; 1 seal, value 6d.; and 1 watch-chain, value 6d.; his goods; and before, at the time of, and after, feloniously beating, striking, and using other personal violence to him.

PATRICK KEEFE . I am an upholsterer, and live at Pleasant-place, Pitt-street, St. George's-road, Southwark. On the night of the 31st of July, about eleven o'clock, I was returning home in St. George's-road, and was suddenly knocked down, and, when down, I found the prisoner in the act of taking my watch out of my pocket—I called out "Police," and tried to take the watch from him—he held the Watch, and I held the seals, until Lee came up—there were two persons attacked me—the one who got away knocked me down, and the prisoner took my watch—I am certain he is the man—the watch produced is mine—I am certain.
Prisoner. Q. You say I had the watch in my hand, and you had the seals in your hand? A. Yes—Lee came and secured you.

RICHARD LEE . I am a boot and shoe-maker, and live at No. 17, Gable-street, Southwark. I saw the prosecutor in St. George's-road, walking steadily along—he was knocked down by the prisoner's compa
nion—as soon as he was down, the prisoner snatched the watch from hi fob—he got hold of the seals, and the prisoner had the watch in his hand.
RICHARD PROSSER (police-constable L 53.) I received charge of the prisoner, and have the watch.

Prisoners Defence. I was returning home and heard a call for a po
liceman—I went over, and saw the gentleman lying in the road—I was walking away, and the constable laid bold of me, and said I must go with him—I never touched the watch.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

2555.
JOHN WHEELER was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of July at
Battersea, 14 sovereigns, the monies of
Thomas Smith, his master, in his dwelling-house.

THOMAS SMITH . I keep the White Hart at Battersea—the prisoner was my pot-boy. On the 27th of July, about half-past ten o'clock in the morning, I missed fourteen sovereigns from my till—the key of the kitchen door will unlock the bar-door, but I did not know it then—I saw my money safe at half-past six that morning—the till was locked—there are two tills, one inside the other—the inner one goes within four inches of the bottom—this money was between the two tills—when we want the money to change, the inner till is taken out, and then we get to the gold and silver—there was 9l. 3s. in silver in a bag, and 27l. 10s. in gold—I lost no silver—there was a shilling dropped in the bar—I have not found any of the gold—I found the till still locked—if we go out, the till is locked, and the key put between two liquor-tubs—it was found there—I keep the key of the bar in my pocket—I charged the prisoner as soon as the money was missed.

MARY COOPER . I am in the service of Mr. Smith. On the morning of the 27th of July, about a quarter to seven o'clock, the prisoner cue into the kitchen—he asked where master was—I said he was outside—he said no more, but went and took the key of the parlour door, and tried the bar door—he said that was no use—then he went to the kitchen-door—he said, "This is the one"—he then went into the bar—I saw him stand with his hands close to the till—when he came out, he put his hand into his right-hand pocket, and said, "All I have taken is two cigars"—master was in the yard at the time, at work—mistress had not come out of her room.

Prisoner. She came and asked me to come and sit down by the side of her, and asked me if I had unlocked the bar. Witness. No, I never spoke to him—I did not ask him why he wanted the key to open the bar-door—I was alarmed when I saw it—when mistress came down and missed the money, she asked me, and I said I had not seen any money—I was taken up on suspicion—I did not tell my master of it.

JOHN PAYNE (police-constable V 11.) The prisoner and Cooper were both brought to the Wandsworth station—Cooper said several times to the prisoner, "John, you have got the money, why don't you give it up?"—I told her not to say anything—she said, "He has got the money, I saw him go in"—he made no answer.

JOSEPH TIGHE (police-constable V 199.) I received change of the pri
soners—on the way to the station, Cooper said in the prisoner's presence, "I have not got the money, John has got it, I saw him at the till"—she said, "John, tell me where the money is, and I will go back and get it, and spare all further trouble"—he made no reply—I found 2l. 4s. 6d. in silver, and 10 1/2 d. in copper on the prisoner, and 1s. 4d. on Cooper about an hour after the robbery was discovered.

Prisoner. The money that was taken from me, was money I had by me for setting up skittles, and 3s. a week for wages—I was two months and three weeks with him, and 18s. I had for a watch that was raffled at the Waterman's Arms, Mr. Prior's.

SAMUEL JORDAN . I had a game at skittles with the prisoner some time before the robbery—I lost 1s.—I asked him to lend me one—he said he had only 2 1/2 d.—I cannot tell How long this was before the robbery—I sup
pose about u month—I know that he raffled a watch—I cannot tell whe
ther it was his own or not—I know he had one, and he sold it by a raffle.
Prisoner's Defence. He had 1s. worth of halfpence, and if you lend him anything, he will not pay you again.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice William.

2556.
WILLIAM BAVIN was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
James Nash, on the 20th of August, and cutting and wounding him in and upon the head, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.
Mr. Charnoch conducted the Prosecution.

JAMES NASH . I am a chair and sofa maker, and live in Broadwall, Stamford-street, Surrey—the prisoner was my journeyman. On Satur
day night last, about eleven o'clock, he came to be settled with—he pro
duced his account to me—there was a difference between us as to the charges, which were more than I thought I should pay—he called me a b—ferret-eyed looking b—, and a shuffling trickster, said said he should like to give me something—I then sent for a policeman, who heard me tell him, what he had done I would pay him for, and when the other work was finished, I would settle for that—he then appeared more calm, and the constable left—I proceeded to settle with him—he went and sat at the end of the room, and I was settling with the other men—while I was sit
ting down writing, he got up, came behind me, and in an instant I felt a tremendous crash on my head, three times; had I not put my hand up, to save the second blow, I believe death must have been the consequence, for I received that blow on my hand instead of my head—I cannot say who struck the blow—I became insensible, and recollect nothing more till I found myself reviving in the surgeon's shop—I was afterwards attended by the surgeon of St. Thomas's Hospital—I managed to go out a little way on Sunday evening, but felt so faint I was obliged to return.

WILLIAM BUCHANAN . I am in the employ of Mr. Nash—I was there on Saturday evening while he and the prisoner were settling some accounts—there was a dispute with the prisoner—a policeman was sent for, and he became quiet—after that he sat down in the room by himself—the pro
secutor began to settle with another man—I saw the prisoner get off his seat, walk round behind the prosecutor, take an empty champagne bottle off the drawers, and strike the prosecutor over the head with it as hard as he could, apparently—master had his hat off, and was sitting at the table—he struck him three times with it—he said nothing—the prosecutor got up and went out—he staggered outside the door—his head bled a good deal—the bottle was broken all to pieces—I think it broke with the se
cond blow, and the third was given with the neck of it—I ran to master's assistance, went over to the doctor's to him, and saw him sitting, bleeding in a chair—he was sensible then—the prisoner was quite sober—I gave him in charge.

JAMES MURRAY . I am a carpenter, and joiner. I live at No. 2, Black-horse-court, Farringdon-street. On Saturday evening last, I was at Mr. Wash's house, and heard a dispute about the prisoner's account—I went in with the policeman, who left—the prosecutor was sitting at the table—the prisoner took up a bottle—he pushed a man against me as I stood in the passage, to get at the bottle—he was behind Mr. Nash—he struck Mr. Nash three times across the head with it, as hard as he could—part of the

bottle flew over me—the last blow was struck with the neck of it—Nash bled, and was taken to a doctor's—the prisoner came out of the room—I seized him, and gave him to the policeman—he was perfectly sober.

GEORGE SMITH . I am a policeman. On Saturday evening last I was called in to Nash—there were words between him and the prisoner—they were quieter, and before I had got a few yards from the house, I heard a dreadful smash, and a cry of, "Murder and police"—I went back—Nash passed me as I went to the house—the blood was running from his head—I have his clothes here—I took the prisoner into custody.

HENRY PETTNER FREEMAN . I am a surgeon and dresser at St. Tho
mas's hospital. Nash has been under my care since Tuesday—I examined his head on Tuesday—it had been dressed before I saw it—he had an in
cised wound, similar to one made by glass, about an inch, or rather more, long—it was only one wound—it extended nearly to the bone—it was not dangerous, but might have become so—he complained of pain in his head, but had no fever—I saw the fragments of the bottle—it appears to be a common champagne bottle—I consider that a dangerous sort of instrument.
Prisoner's Defence. He refused to pay my wages; I told him that was wrong; he got up, seized hold of me, and told me to protect myself, I got hold of the bottle, and hit him twice over the head.

GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor .—
Confined Six Months.
Before Mr. Recorder.

2557.
EDWARD THOMAS was indicted
for breaking and entering the counting-house of
Thomas Evans and another, on the 13th of August, at St. Saviour, Southwark, and stealing therein 1 pair of spectacles, value 1s. 6d.; 1 hat, value 2s.; 1 coat, value 6s.; the goods of Thomas Evans; and 3 pairs of compasses, value 1s. 6d.; 2400 pence, and 4800 halfpence, the property of Thomas Evans and another.

THOMAS EVANS . I am in partnership with John Lascelles, of Great Guildford-street, St. Saviour, Southwark. On the 13th of August, about half-past six in the morning, I went to the premises, and found the counting-house door open, and the desks forced—I missed out of my desk a pair of spec
tacles, three pairs of compasses, and some loose copper of my own; also some coats, a waistcoat, and hat—the key of the iron-chest, which had been locked up in my desk, was taken out—20l. in copper belonging to the firm was gone from the chest—I had locked the desk about half-past one the day before—the counting-house is in a yard, at the back of the house of Mr. Burgess, our clerk—it is enclosed by a wall, and there is a door leading to Mr. Lascelles premises from it.

JOHN LASCELLES, JUN . I live with my father, and am employed in the counting-house—about half-past seven or a quarter to eight o'clock, I shut up the counting-house, locked the door, and took the key—it was all safe at nine o'clock.

REDMAN WELSH (police-constable M 109.) On the 13th of August, about two o'clock in the morning, I was on duty in Guildford-street, South
wark, and saw the prisoner and another—I followed them into Gravel-lane—they saw me, and separated—I followed, stopped the prisoner, and found 6s. 3 1/2 d. in copper, three pairs of compasses, a pair of spectacles, and case

on him—he was wearing a coat, waistcoat, and hat, which I now pro
duce—be had them on.
MR. EVANS re-examined. This is my coat and waistcoat—they were taken from a box—the lock of the door appeared to have been picked—the other articles are mine.

CHARLES LEWIS . I am a policeman. I took these articles off the pri
soner's back.
JOHN MILLS (police-constable M 31.) I found a coat in the prosecutor's counting-house—I made the prisoner try it on—it appeared to fit him.

Prisoner's Defence. It is not ray coat; I was coming from Horseley-down-stairs, went into a public-house, and bought the things of a man who owned them; I saw the two policemen drinking together when they stopped me.

REDMAN WELSH
re-examined. We stopped him 150 yards from the counting-house—we were not drinking—there is no public-house in the street.
Prisoner. A young gentleman in the street with them had got a bottle.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Ten Years.
Before Mr. Baron Rolfe.

2558.
WILLIAM TAYLOR was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Robert Collins, on the 22nd of August, and cutting and wounding him on his head, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.—2nd COUNT, stating his intent to be to resist and prevent his lawful apprehension and detainer.

ROBERT COLLINS (police-constable V 108.) On Monday, the 22nd of August, between six and seven o'clock in the evening I was on duty on Kennington Common—there was a meeting there of three or four thousand persons, I should say—I did not hear any speaking myself—we were ordered clear the Common, and shortly after doing so I saw the prisoner in the Kennington-road, throwing stones at the constables who were on the Com
mon—the last stone he threw struck me on my right hand—I got over the rils, and took hold of him with my left hand—be resisted, but through the bow on my right hand he succeeded in getting my staff from me, and strug
ged with me in the road—he struck me on the head with my own staff, which stnned me for the moment—I was assisted by the constable to a doctor's—ve were struggling at the time he struck me, and both fell down on the footway—he was underneath—he struck me twice, but only once on the he—the other blow was on the shoulder—I was stunned, and cannot tell who her he struck me after the second time—when I came to myself two conables of the L division had him in custody—I did not see my staff agai till I got to Tower-street station—it was taken from him—the ser
gean who took the charge gave it me.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What time did you go on duty that right at Kennington Common? A. Shortly after six o'clock—there had on a meeting gathering together for some time before we went there—he people were not allowed to go on the Common after the police were stioned there—there might be 500 police there, as near as I can tell—to sergeants and inspectors were on horseback—the police them
selves are not—I have no recollection of seeing a constable on horseback—the meeting had been dispersed several minutes when I saw the prisoner throw she at the police—the police had nothing to drink on the Common there were no cans of drink brought on the Common for them

—I swear that—they had some beer about six o'clock, when we were sta
tioned in reserve in Kennington-lane—I had none myself—I did not feel inclined to have any—I could have had it if I had liked to purchase it the same as any other constable—any man that liked to have half-a-pint of beer might have had it—I had taken nothing since my tea—I had not been drinking in the course of the day—I had been in bed all day—I never had anything to drink from the time I left home, which was tea, and pre
vious to that I never tasted malt liquor of any description—I did not re
main at the station-house that night—I went to Kennington-lane after this happened—I did not to my knowledge see the prisoner's wife come to Tower-street station after this happened—I was not singing and keeping it up at the station after I had received the blow on my head—I felt too unwell—I did not sing at the station that night, while the prisoner was in custody—I remained at the station about a quarter of an hour after the prisoner was locked up—I never sat down there after he was given in charge—the prisoner was standing on the high road from Kennington-gate to the Horns when he was throwing the stones, on the right hand side from Brixton, the side nearest the Common—there were a great many people standing there—they extended across the road—it is a wide road—I was standing on the Common, not more than a dozen yards from the railings—the prisoner was standing just outside the railings—I cannot recollect who the persons were on each side of him—I saw other men, but seeing him amuse himself with throwing stones, he took my attention more than anybody—I seized him with my left hand, holding my staff in my right—he seized my staff—we scuffled for about a minute—I did not get the better of him—he fell down—it was not in the act of falling under me that he struck the blows—it was just as he was going, with his back towards the path—he was in the act of falling when be struck me—it was after the scuffle—we bad a scuffle of course when we were down—I swear that I had not received the blow on my head, on the Common before I say the prisoner—it was a blow from my own staff from him—I was the first person that seized on the prisoner—it was not Lutsford—I laid hold I him before Lutsford got over the rails—Lutsford came up two minutes afterwards—the greater part of the people were on the Common at the time the prisoner was throwing the stones.

HENRY LUTSFORD (police-constable L 87.) I was at Kenningon Common last Monday evening—there were a number of people assembled there—I assisted in dispersing them—I saw the prisoner standing outside the rails in Kennington-road, just by the edge of the footpath, by that I could see of him—I cannot say whether he was on the path or in the kennel—I saw him standing there among the people—I was working by close to Collins, and I saw the prisoner hoist his hand, and throw a stone on to the Common towards where the police were—the police were just opposite the place where he threw—I was close to Collins at the time—I did not see whether the stone hit him—my eye was fixed on pri
soner, and I was about to get over the rails, but Collins was over rails before I was, and had got the prisoner by the collar with his left and—I was about to get through the mob as quick as I could to assist him in taking him, when I saw the prisoner take the truncheon from Collins's right hand—a struggle ensued, and I saw him strike Collins On the head with the truncheon—Collins's hat was off—it fell off in the ruggle, I

believe before he was struck—I saw blood flow—I then laid hold of the pri
soner, and we all three fell to the ground together—I rescued Collins's truncheon from the prisoner's hand as he was about to strike him again—another constable came to our assistance, and we took him to the sta
tion.

Cross-examined. Q. Was the prisoner in the act of falling at the time the blow was struck? A. I believe he was—we were all in the act of falling together—Smith No. 119, was the other constable—he is not here—I did not see Collins's hat go off—Collins had hold of the prisoner first, not me—I did not remain at Tower-street station all that night—I stopped there till I had lodged the prisoner there, and then I went back to see where Collins was—I had been in reserve in Kennington-lane before the meeting—I saw some beer there, and I had a pint myself, for which I paid twopence—that was all I had—I had had nothing to drink before that except my tea at breakfast—I had my dinner in Keanington-lane—that was when I had the pint of porter—I believe there were cans of beer, not very large ones—the men were not allowed to have what they liked—Mr. Grinsell, the superintendent, did not allow us more than a pint each.
COURT. Q. How long had yon been in reserte there? A. I think from about half-past ten o'clock in the morning, and remained there all day—we paid for the beer ourselves.

JURY. Q. How did you come on the ground? A. Through the rush of the mob on us—I had hold of the prisoner at the time, and we all fell together—a gentleman, who I believe is a witness, came in to our assistance at the time, besides the constable No. 119.

JOHN BROWN . I am a pensioner from the army, and live in Upper Crown-street, Westminster. I am not of any trade or occupation—last Monday evening, I was on the road that leads by the side of Ken
nington Common, passing in the rear of those who were standing on the footpath, looking over the palings enclosing the Common—I saw the pri
soner, not in the dress he is now in, but in a smock-frock, draw his hand with a stone, and throw it into the Common at the police—I did not see what sort of a stone it was—a policeman immediately jumped over the palings like a shot—the prisoner went a little to his left to conceal himself behind the mob—the policeman immediately seized him by the collar with his left hand—the prisoner resisted violently—the mob journeyed about, shoved both the policeman and the prisoner about, and shooed them, I be
lieve, into the middle of the road, where I saw the prisoner and the police
man down on the road, the policeman uppermost, and the prisoner covered over, with a considerable quantity of blood on him, which I thought flowed from himself, but which I found afterwards was from the policeman's head—I told the policeman that that was the man that threw take stone—I was junted about with the mob—I drew a cane, which I had in my hand, in a menacing manner, at the mob, which kept them back till two or three po
licemen came in and secured the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. In what capacity were you in the army? A. A private soldier, a bombardier, a corporal, a sergeant, a colour-sergeant, and pay-sergeant of a company—I live at Westminster—I happened on this day to be assisting a friend of mine, who is an assessor, to deliver the Income tax papers—I was in front of the Common, and in some few

streets, until nearly the time when this affair occurred—I was not on the Common, but in the road, where there were many hundreds more—I did not see any blows struck by the prisoner—I believe I was the only person who said any thing to the police—I had not come there with any of the police to assist them—I was not hired by the Government—after I had distributed the Income tax papers, I thought I would have a look at these good boys that were going to make gentlemen of us all, and equally divide every thing—I wanted to see what a show these Chartists made.

DAVID TAYLOR . I am a surgeon. Collins was brought to my surgery, and I attended him—he had an ordinary contused wound of the head of a very trifling character—I have no doubt it is well now, or nearly so—I have not seen it, because I have been engaged here during the last week.

JURY. Q. Was the wound of that magnitude as to cover the prisoner with blood? A. Trifling wounds will sometimes produce a large quantity of blood without any serious importance—there was nothing in the nature of the wound to lead me to suppose it impossible that it should cause a good deal of blood.

JOSEPH HOLDSWORTH . I am a plasterer, and live in Dove-row, Hack
ney-road. I know the prisoner—on Monday, the 22nd of August, we were working for Mr. Tully at some houses in Lambeth-road, about a quarter of an hour's walk from Kennington-Common—the prisoner left work at six o'clock that evening—I heard him say in the course of the day that he had some tools at some other job, and he should go and fetch them in the evening, and he left with that intention—he only worked with me a week—he seemed a sober, peaceable man.
COURT. Q. Were you at the meeting? A. No.

ROBERT COLLINS
re-examined. I saw the prisoner throw eight or nine different stones before the one that struck me—other people were throw
ing stones after that and before that, but not at the time the stone struck me—the prisoner was standing among the crowd, outside the rails, on the footpath, when he threw the last stone that hit me, and after that he was hiding behind the people—he was at the head of the footpath when he threw four or five, and then he came to the edge of the rails, and threw the last two or three—there were a good many people on the path—I was ten or twelve-yards from the rails—I could see him, being much the taller man there, and having a white frock on—I saw him come forward and throw the stone, and then run back among the crowd—I thought it was time to take him when he struck me—I did not take him before, because I saw the danger of going over the rails singly—I might have got killed, and should, no doubt, but for the assistance of Lutsford.

HENRY LUTSFORD
re-examined. The prisoner must have been by the curb of the footpath when he threw the stone—I saw the place on Collins's hand afterwards—I did not see the prisoner standing near the rails at all—I saw Mr. Brown with his cane after the prisoner was in custody—he kept back the crowd in the best manner he could—the crowd pushed us down.

JURY. Q. Is it not possible that Collins might have received the blow from the truncheon of some other policeman? A. There was no other policeman there but me till after he was secured, and when I got bold of the prisoner he had the truncheon in his right hand—I saw that Collins's hand was bruised at the back, which rendered it useless—we were on our logs again when Smith (No. 119) came in—we then took him over the
rails into the common among our men, to secure him there till we got a conveyance—we were obliged to take him away in a cab, the mob was so great—they threatened to rescue him.

JOHN BROWN
re-examined. I do not believe I was a yard from the pri
soner when the stone was thrown—he had on a white smock-frock and a cap—I have not the least doubt of his throwing the stone—I saw one other man throw a stone a few yards before I came up to the prisoner—the pri
soner drew his hand so near my face that I could not help seeing him—I was passing along to leave the ground.

JOSEPH HOLDSWORTH
re-examined. I parted with the prisoner at six o'clock that evening—he had a shiny cap and smock-frock on—it was not white—he had been working in it for a month or so.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY on the 2nd Count.—Strongly recommended to mercy on account of his good character .—
Confined Three Months.
Before Mr. Recorder.

2559.
MARY ANN NYE was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of Au
gust, 1 box, value 5s.; 1 work-box, value 4s.; 3 yards of ribbon, value 6d.; 2 brooches, value 4s.; 1 printed book, value 6d.; 2 petticoats, value 5s.; 11 gowns, value 1l. 19s.; 3 pillow-cases, value 2s.; 1 boa, value 5s.; 1 pair of stays, value 2s.; 4 shawls, value 10s.; 1 cape, value 3s.; 14 aprons, value 12s.; 18 handkerchiefs, value 10s.; 1 pair of boots, value 2s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 1s.; 5 pairs of stockings, value 2s. 6d.; 3 sheets, value 7s.; 1 housewife, value 6d.; 12 napkins, value 3s.; 2 pairs of cuffs, value 6d.; 6 spoons, value 2s.; 1 pair of sugar-tongs, value 6d.; 8 oz. weight of tobacco, value 2s.; 24 cigars, value 1s.; 1 bonnet, value 2s.; and 8 yards of printed cotton, value 1s.; the goods of
James Illman: and
WILLIAM PRATT
, for feloniously inciting and procuring the said Mary Ann Nye to commit the said felony.—2nd COUNT, for feloniously receiving the said goods, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.
MR. BODKIN conducted the Prosecution.

JAMES ILLMAN . I keep the Yew Tree public-house, at Reigate—the prisoner Pratt is a working gardener, and has been in the habit of coming to my house as a customer for about twelve months—I did not suspect any thing wrong between him and my wife. On Wednesday night, the 3rd of August, about ten o'clock, I missed my wife from my house, and afterwards missed, a quantity of property—Nye is my wife's cousin, and had been on a visit at Reigate for a short time previous to this—she had not been stopping at my house, but had been there several times—I did not see Nye leave on the 3rd of August—I was out—I came up to London that night, and gave information to the police—I went to the Elephant and Castle, at Newing
ton, a little before eleven next morning, and there found a box of mine, addressed to "Miss Nye"—I waited there all that day and the next, till about two, and the prisoner Nye then came in a cab—she asked for that box, and it was delivered to her—after she had got it, and had got into the cab again, I went up and asked her if she knew what property she had got there—she said yes, it was her own—I called a policeman, and gave her into custody, and he took possession of the box—I afterwards went to the Duke of Wellington public-house—I do not know in what

street it is—it is about a mile and a half from the Elephant and Castle—I there found Pratt, with two umbrellas, a basket, and a bandbox—I gave him into custody, and told him it was for stealing my property—I said nothing about my wife—I left him in charge of the officers, and then went to look for my wife—I found her at the top of that same street.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long have you been married? A. About four years—my wife's name was Ann Nye before I married her—she was not a widow—I have never complained of her con
duct before with anybody, nor of her absence on any occasion—she has not been living with me since this has happened—she was at my house one night, the night we went down by the night-van late—she remained there with her sister, and next morning she went down to her mother's—I have seen her during the last week—she has been living with her sister, away from me—I have slept in the same house—when Nye came for the box, I asked if she knew what she had got there—she said, "Yes"—I then told her it was my property, and gave her into custody—that was all that took place.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you say anything to Pratt, when you found him? A. I said, "You are a pretty fellow, are you not?"—he said, "What have I done?" and I said, "You have ran away with my wife and all my property"—this was on Friday, the 5th—my wife left home on Wednesday, the 3rd—I had seen Pratt in my house a little before ten o'clock that evening—I was down in the cellar for about ten minutes when my wife left, and I missed her when I came up.

ANN ILLMAN . I am the prosecutor's wife. I left my husband's house with Pratt on the 3rd of August—Nye had been at Reigate for some days before—I did not tell her anything about Pratt's attention to me—he asked me if she should go and pack up my things, and she went up stairs and packed them up—I first conversed with Nye about Pratt about three days before that—she asked me to go away—I did not say that I would or would not—she said if I wanted to go away I was to go with Pratt—I had not told her anything about him before that—he had spoken to her—she told me that they had been talking together, and she wished me to go away with him—I did not exactly agree to that—I did at last go away with him, with a great deal of persuasion by both of them—Pratt asked me what I was going to take with me—I told him I did not know—he said I was to take as much as I could with me, and I was to take as much money as I could, and the watch besides, and leave my husband penniless—I was very much shocked at that proposal—he said he could not take any
